FARMERS (N=27) WILL TEST ASD IN THEIR HTS (BABY TRIALS) AND PROVIDE FEEDBACK ON EFFICACY AND POTENTIAL ADOPTION. FULLY REPLICATED MOTHER TRIALS WILL BE CONDUCTED TO DEMONSTRATE DIFFERENT ASD TREATMENTS. SINCE ASD RELIES ON SOIL AMENDMENT WITH A SOURCE OF CARBON, USUALLY AGRICULTURAL BYPRODUCTS LIKE WHEAT MIDDS OR SPENT DISTILLER'S GRAINS, RESEARCH IS NEEDED TO OPTIMIZE NUTRITION FOR TOMATOES. STUDIES WILL BE CONDUCTED TO UNDERSTAND NUTRIENT DYNAMICS AND AVAILABILITY AFTER ASD WITH DIFFERENT CARBON SOURCES, RESULTING IN NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS FOR GROWERS. FINALLY, RESULTS OF THE PROJECT WILL BE COMMUNICATED TO STAKEHOLDERS USING FACTSHEETS, SHORT VIDEOS, WEBINARS, BLOGS, AND ONLINE AND IN-PERSON PRESENTATIONS TO GROWER GROUPS. PROJECT PROGRESS WILL BE MONITORED AND POTENTIAL ADOPTION OF ASD PREDICTED USING OUTCOOME MAPPING. ULTIMATELY, THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE TOMATO PRODUCTION IN HTS, PROMOTE WIDESPREAD ADOPTION OF ASD, AND ENSURE THE AVAILABILITY OF HIGH QUALITY LOCAL TOMATOES TO CONSUMERS.

THERE ARE OVER 14,000 U.S. GOLF COURSES THAT CONTRIBUTE AN ESTIMATED $84 BILLION TO THE U.S. ECONOMY. APPROXIMATELY 70% OF GOLF COURSE SUPERINTENDENTS IN THE MIDWESTERN AND NORTHEASTERN U.S. IDENTIFIED DOLLAR SPOT (CLARIREEDIA JACKSONII) AS THEIR PRIMARY DISEASE. THE AVERAGE SUPERINTENDENT IN EACH RESPECTIVE REGION SPENT $15,000 AND $28,000 PER YEAR ON SYNTHETIC CHEMICALS TO CONTROL DOLLAR SPOT, MORE THAN ANY OTHER DISEASE. A PLANT-BASED ANTIFUNGAL AGENT CALLED POACIC ACID WAS RECENTLY DEVELOPED BY DR. MEHDI KABBAGE AND OTHERS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN - MADISON THAT SHOWED GREAT IN VITRO EFFICACY AGAINST C. JACKSONII AND OTHER IMPORTANT PLANT PATHOGENS, HOWEVER EFFICACY IN THE FIELD WAS INCONSISTENT. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD ON THE INITIAL IN VITRO SUCCESS OF POACIC ACID BY WORKING WITH PRIVATE INDUSTRY (SPECIFICALLY SIMPLOT TURF AND HORTICULTURE) TO DEVELOP NEW FORMULATIONS THAT WILL INCREASE FIELD EFFICACY AND REDUCE RELIANCE ON SYNTHETIC FUNGICIDE USE ON GOLF COURSES. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROPOSAL ARE: 1) IDENTIFY ONE OR MORE EFFECTIVE POACIC ACID FORMULATIONS FOR PATHOGEN SUPPRESSION AND TURF HEALTH; 2) DEVELOP STRATEGIES FOR INTEGRATING POACIC ACID INTO A HOLISTIC TURFGRASS DISEASE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM; AND 3) CREATE EFFECTIVE OUTREACH AND COMMUNICATION TOOLS THAT DISSEMINATE THE KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM THIS RESEARCH TO GOLF COURSE SUPERINTENDENTS ACROSS THE NORTHERN U.S.

THE EUROPEAN PEPPER MOTH (EPM) (DUPONCHELIA FOVEALIS) IS A MAJOR, YET LARGELY UNRECOGNIZED EXOTIC INVASIVE INSECT PEST OF NURSERY, VEGETABLE, FRUIT, AND GREENHOUSE CROPS. LARVAL EPM FEED ON FOLIAGE, FRUIT, AND FREQUENTLY ON LOWER STEMS OF PLANTS, CAUSING STEM DIEBACK, PLANT DEATH, AND ECONOMIC LOSS, WITH SEVERAL GROWERS ESTIMATING AN ANNUAL ECONOMIC LOSSGREATER THAN $200,000 FROM EPM. CURRENT MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES ARE INEFFECTIVE, BECAUSE INFORMATION ABOUT EPM DISTRIBUTION, POPULATION CYCLES, PLANT PREFERENCES, AND EFFECTIVE INSECTICIDES IS LACKING. EXTENSION PERSONNEL, GROWERS, THE IR-4 PROJECT, AND TRADE ASSOCIATIONS HAVE RECOGNIZED EPM AS ONE OF THE TOP PRIORITY PESTS THAT NEEDS TO BE ADDRESSED. THIS MULTI-STATE PROJECT (TX AND NC) SPANS ACROSS A LARGE AREA OF THE EPM RANGE, PROVIDING DATA AND INSIGHT RELEVANT TO SOUTHERN USA. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO INCREASE ADOPTION OF EFFECTIVE INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT (IPM) PRACTICES AND DECREASE ECONOMIC LOSS DUE TO EPM BY INVESTIGATING THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES: (1) DETERMINE THE DISTRIBUTION AND PHENOLOGY OF EPM; (2) DETERMINE EPM PREFERENCE AND DAMAGE TO NURSERY CROP SPECIES AND CULTIVARS; (3) DETERMINE HOW IRRIGATION AND FERTILIZER PRACTICES CAN INFLUENCE DAMAGE CAUSED BY EPM; AND (4) DETERMINE THE EFFICACY OF STANDARD AND BIOLOGICAL INSECTICIDES TO MANAGE EPM. RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY WILL BE PUBLISHED IN PEER-REVIEWED PAPERS, INDUSTRY MAGAZINES, UNIVERSITY EXTENSION ARTICLES, WEBSITES, AND THROUGH EDDMAPS.

THIS IS AN APPLIED RESEARCH (ARDP, SINGLE-FUNCTION) MULTI-STATE PROJECT THAT CONTRIBUTES TO CPPM FOCUS AREA 1 - PLANT PROTECTION TACTICS AND TOOLS. STAKEHOLDERS FROM ACROSS MIDWEST, SOUTH, AND CENTRAL GREAT PLAINS OF THE U.S. HAVE IDENTIFIED PIGWEEDS (PALMER AMARANTH AND WATERHEMP) AS ONE OF THE MOST PROBLEMATIC AND ECONOMICALLY DAMAGING WEED SPECIES. BOTH PIGWEEDS CURRENTLY POSE A SERIOUS THREAT TO SUSTAINABLE CROP PRODUCTION DUE TO A LIMITED EFFECTIVE HERBICIDE OPTIONS. WIDESPREAD MULTIPLE RESISTANCE TO 6-7 DIFFERENT HERBICIDE SITES-OF-ACTION HAS INCREASED THE NEED AND THE DESIRE FOR IPM-BASED SOLUTIONS FOR MANAGING PIGWEEDS IN SOYBEAN-BASED CROPPING SYSTEMS OF THE U.S. FOR THIS STAKEHOLDER-IDENTIFIED RESEARCH, WE PROPOSE TO: 1) EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF TWO ECOLOGICALLY-BASED TACTICS, NAMELY COVER CROP AND HARVEST WEED SEED CONTROL (CHAFF LINING AND WEED SEED DESTRUCTOR), WITHIN AN INTEGRATED WEED MANAGEMENT (IWM) FRAMEWORK, FOR MANAGING PIGWEED SEED BANKS IN SOYBEAN, AND 2) QUANTIFY THE ECONOMIC BENEFITS AND RISKS OF ADOPTING A DIVERSIFIED IWM PROGRAM TO MITIGATE HERBICIDE RESISTANCE. WE WILL CONDUCT MULTI-LOCATION (IA, AR, AND KS) FIELD AND GREENHOUSE/LABORATORY STUDIES TO DEVELOP AND INTEGRATE THESE ECOLOGICAL TACTICS THAT HAVE A HIGH LIKELIHOOD OF REDUCING PIGWEED SEED BANKS AND EXPOSURE OF THIS SPECIES TO HERBICIDES, THEREBY REDUCING SELECTION FOR HERBICIDE RESISTANCE EVOLUTION ACROSS THE THREE MAJOR SOYBEAN PRODUCTION REGIONS. IMPLEMENTATION AND ADOPTION OF THESE ECOLOGICALLY-BASED IWM STRATEGIES WILL REDUCE POTENTIAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS AND APPLICATOR EXPOSURE PROBLEMS ASSOCIATED WITH INCREASED PESTICIDE USE. RESULTS FROM THIS IWM PROJECT WILL BE DISSEMINATED ACROSS GEOGRAPHIC BOUNDARIES TO MEET THE NATIONAL IPM ROADMAP GOALS.

KEY CHALLENGES FACED BY ORGANIC AND CONVENTIONAL PRODUCERS INCLUDE MANAGING MULTIPLE PEST COMPLEXES WHILE BEING HOSPITABLE TO BENEFICIAL ORGANISMS. THOUGH USING ORGANIC AND SOFT PESTICIDES SUCH AS PLANT-BASED INSECTICIDES AND TILLAGE CAN SUPPRESS INSECT AND WEED PESTS, THESE PRACTICES CAN HAVE NEGATIVE CONSEQUENCES ON BENEFICIAL ORGANISMS ABOVE AND BELOW THE SOIL. GENERALLY, THESE TWO PEST COMPLEXES ARE STUDIED SEPARATELY. HOWEVER, THERE EXISTS A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO ADDRESS THESE PEST ISSUES CONCOMITANTLY, AND CONSEQUENTLY DEVELOP PEST MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT ADDRESS CROP VULNERABILITY TO INSECTS, WEEDS AND NEMATODES WITHOUT COMPROMISING AGROECOSYSTEM HEALTH. THUS, THE GOAL OF OUR MULTIDISCIPLINARY TEAM IS TO DEVELOP AND DISSEMINATE HUSBANDRY PRACTICES THAT WILL HELP PRODUCERS MITIGATE MULTIPLE PEST COMPLEXES WITHOUT IMPAIRING BENEFICIAL ORGANISMS. THREE ECOFRIENDLY PRACTICES (BIOSOLARIZATION, COVER CROPPING, AND STRIP-TILLAGE) WILL BE DEPLOYED AND INVESTIGATED JOINTLY. THE LONG-TERM GOAL IS TO DEVELOP SUSTAINABLE, LOW COST AND LOW INPUT PRACTICES TO IMPROVE SOIL HEALTH, PEST SUPPRESSION AND CROP PRODUCTIVITY ON CONVENTIONAL AND ORGANIC FARMS. TO THIS END, FIELD TRIALS AND/OR EXTENSION ACTIVITIES WILL OCCUR AT UNIVERSITY AND FARMERS' FIELD SITES. SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO DEMONSTRATE THE SYNERGISTIC BENEFITS OF BIOSOLARIZATION, COVER CROPPING AND STRIP TILLAGE FOR: (1) REDUCING CROP PESTS; (2) ENHANCING YIELDS AND BENEFICIAL ORGANISMS BELOW AND ABOVE THE SOIL; AND (3) DISSEMINATING KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM OBJECTIVES 1 AND 2 TO STAKEHOLDERS.

SCB IS ROUTINELY RANKED AS THE TOP INSECT PEST AMONG VEGETABLE GROWERS NATIONWIDE, NOT JUST IN CUCURBITS BUT ACROSS ALL CROP TYPES. IN A SURVEY OF >1,000 DIVERSIFIED ORGANIC AND TRANSITIONING VEGETABLE GROWERS FROM ACROSS 16 EASTERN U.S. STATES, CUCUMBER BEETLE WAS THE MOST FREQUENTLY NAMED PEST WHEN FARMERS WERE ASKED TO IDENTIFY WHICH INSECTS ARE 'USUALLY PRESENT' AND 'DIFFICULT TO CONTROL' (I. KAPLAN, UNPUBLISHED DATA). WE ALSO CONDUCTED A RECENT (2019) SURVEY OF 106 CONVENTIONAL CUCURBIT PRODUCERS IN THE PD'S STUDY REGION (INDIANA, ILLINOIS, MICHIGAN, OHIO), RESULTING IN SIMILAR RESPONSES. CUCUMBER BEETLES WERE IDENTIFIED BY 77% OF THE RESPONDENTS AS PRESENT IN THEIR FIELDS AND WAS THE TOP INSECT LISTED WHEN ASKED TO WRITE IN "WHICH INSECT DID YOU HAVE THE MOST PROBLEMS MANAGING IN YOUR CUCURBIT FIELDS IN 2018?".THE OUTCOME FROM THESE DIRECT MAIL SURVEYS CORRESPONDS WELL WITH NUMEROUS STATE- AND CROP-SPECIFIC REPORTS OF STAKEHOLDER-IDENTIFIED IPM NEEDS FROM THE NATIONAL INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT DATABASE (HTTPS://IPMDATA.IPMCENTERS.ORG/). THE SCB IS MENTIONED AS A PRIMARY PEST OF CONCERN IN VIRTUALLY ALL EASTERN U.S. CUCURBIT CROP PROFILES, INFESTING 78-100% OF ACREAGE. EXAMPLES OF SPECIFIC REPORTS INCLUDE:PUMPKINS IN VIRGINIA: "BOTH THE SPOTTED AND STRIPED CUCUMBER BEETLES (ADULTS AND LARVAE) MAY SEVERELY REDUCE PUMPKIN PRODUCTIVITY. THESE PESTS ARE THE #1 CONCERN OF GROWERS IN VIRGINIA."WATERMELONS IN MISSOURI: "THE PRIMARY INSECT/MITE PESTS AFFECTING WATERMELON PRODUCTION ANNUALLY IN MISSOURI ARE THE CUCUMBER BEETLE AND SPIDER MITES. THE CUCUMBER BEETLE IS THE NUMBER ONE INSECT PEST."SQUASH IN DELAWARE: "STRIPED CUCUMBER BEETLES, ACALYMMA VITTATA (FABRICIUS), AND SPOTTED CUCUMBER BEETLES, DIABROTICA UNDECIMPUNETATA HOWARDI (BARBER), ARE THE MOST DESTRUCTIVE INSECT PESTS OF CUCUMBERS, SQUASH AND RELATED CROPS IN THE MID-ATLANTIC AREA."PUMPKINS IN PENNSYLVANIA: "CUCUMBER BEETLES ARE A GROUP THAT ARE THE MOST SIGNIFICANT INSECT PEST OF MOST CUCURBITS."WATERMELON IN LOUISIANA: "THE MAJOR INSECT PROBLEM ON WATERMELONS IS CUCUMBER BEETLES."MELONS IN CALIFORNIA: "INSECTICIDES WERE USED ON 76% OF ALL CANTALOUPES GROWN IN CALIFORNIA...THE PRIMARY PESTS TO ALL MELON TYPES TARGETED BY THESE FOLIAR TREATMENTS INCLUDE...CUCUMBER BEETLES."LAST, OUR LOCAL OBSERVATIONS MATCH CONVERSATIONS WITH CUCURBIT (MOSTLY MELON) GROWERS AND ON-FARM PEST SAMPLING CONDUCTED BY THE PD AT 20 WATERMELON FARMS IN INDIANA BETWEEN 2017 AND 2018 (RESULTS REPORTED IN TERNEST ET AL. 2020). RECENTLY (APRIL 2020) WE ALSO PUBLISHED A SERIES OF VIDEOS, FEATURING INTERVIEWS WITH SOME OF THE LARGER MELON PRODUCERS IN THE MIDWEST, WHO DISCUSSED THEIR USE OF INSECTICIDES FOR SCB MANAGEMENT (HTTPS://YOUTU.BE/GRQONJ5EX0M) AND THEIR RELIANCE ON HONEY BEES OR WILD POLLINATORS (HTTPS://YOUTU.BE/CTZQ1PYGMFA). MOST MELON PRODUCTION IN THE WEST OCCURS IN CALIFORNIA, WHERE CUCUMBER BEETLES ARE PRIMARILY AN ISSUE IN THE NORTHERN CENTRAL VALLEY. HERE, THEY ARE A STAKEHOLDER-DEFINED PEST ISSUE (CA PMSP 2016) AND ARE TYPICALLY DESCRIBED AS THE PRIMARY INSECT OF CONCERN BY PEST CONTROL ADVISORS AND GROWERS.WHILE THERE ARE CLEARLY REGIONAL DIFFERENCES IN PEST COMPLEXES AND SITE-SPECIFIC PEST HISTORIES OR ISSUES, THE ABOVE COMBINATION OF GROWER SURVEYS, IPM REPORTS, ON-FARM OBSERVATIONS, AND FARMER INTERVIEWS COLLECTIVELY IDENTIFY THE CUCUMBER BEETLE COMPLEX AS THE SINGLE GREATEST INSECT THREAT TO CUCURBIT PRODUCTION AND SUSTAINABILITY.

THE EVOLUTION AND SPREAD OF GLYPHOSATE AND MULTIPLE HERBICIDE-RESISTANT WEEDS HAS LED TO SIGNIFICANT INCREASES IN HERBICIDE USE AND FARM-LEVEL WEED CONTROL COSTS WITHIN NO-TILL FIELD CROP PRODUCTIONS SYSTEMS ACROSS U.S. REGIONS.DEVELOPMENT AND COMMUNICATION OF PROACTIVE, INTEGRATED WEED MANAGEMENT (IWM) STRATEGIES THAT EMPLOY NON-CHEMICAL TACTICS TO REDUCE THE LIKELIHOOD OF HERBICIDE RESISTANCE EVOLUTION IS URGENTLY NEEDED. COVER CROPPING IS UNIQUE AMONG POTENTIAL IWM TACTICS IN THAT CURRENT INTEREST AND ADOPTION IS PRIMARILY DRIVEN BY LONG-TERM SUSTAINABLE AGROECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT GOALS. UNDERSTANDING OF INTERACTIONS BETWEEN HIGH-RESIDUE COVER CROPS AND USE OF SOIL-APPLIED RESIDUAL HERBICIDES IS A SIGNIFICANT KNOWLEDGE GAP THAT PREVENTS IMPROVED EFFICACY OF INTEGRATED TACTICS. OUR GOAL IS TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW HIGH-RESIDUE COVER CROP MANAGEMENT TACTICS (TERMINATION TIMING, SPECIES SELECTION, RESIDUE MANAGEMENT) INFLUENCE THE FATE AND EFFICACY OF SOIL-APPLIED RESIDUAL HERBICIDES. FIELD EXPERIMENTS WILL BE CONDUCTED TO (1) QUANTIFY THE INTERACTIVE EFFECTS OF COVER CROP RESIDUE AND RESIDUAL HERBICIDE PROPERTIES ON HERBICIDE FATE PROCESSES, INCLUDING INTERCEPTION, RETENTION, AND SOIL BIOAVAILABILITY, AND (2) EVALUATE INTERACTIONS BETWEEN HIGH-RESIDUE COVER CROP AND RESIDUAL HERBICIDE MANAGEMENT TACTICS ON POPULATION DYNAMICS OF MULTIPLE HERBICIDE RESISTANT WEEDS. ANTICIPATED IMPACTS OF OUR INTEGRATED RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROJECT INCLUDE IMPROVED PRODUCER KNOWLEDGE OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), CONCEPTUAL APPROACHES, AND LONG-TERM MANAGEMENT GOALS FOR EMPLOYING PROACTIVE IWM TO MANAGE AND PREVENT HERBICIDE RESISTANCE.

THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THE MANAGEMENT OF SPOTTED-WING DROSOPHILA (SWD), DROSOPHILA SUZUKII (MATSUMURA), A KEY PEST OF SOFT-SKINNED FRUIT CROPS IN THE USA. SINCE 2008, IT HAS CONTINUED TO IMPACT FRUIT CROPS SEVERELY, AND IMPLEMENTING COST-EFFECTIVE, SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS REMAINS AN URGENT NATIONAL PRIORITY. THERE IS ZERO TOLERANCE FOR THE INFESTATION IN FRESH FRUIT, SO MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS RELY ON BROAD-SPECTRUM INSECTICIDES, RESULTING IN SIGNIFICANT ECONOMIC AND NON-TARGET EFFECTS. THE INTENSIVE MANAGEMENT FOR THIS PEST INCLUDES SECONDARY PEST OUTBREAKS THAT OCCUR WHEN INSECTICIDES DISRUPT OTHER PESTS' BIOLOGICAL CONTROL. THEREFORE, NEW NON-INSECTICIDE MANAGEMENT OPTIONS ARE NEEDED. THE MOST PROMISING BIOLOGICAL CONTROL OPTION IS INTRODUCING A PARASITOID FROM THE NATIVE RANGE OF SWD IN ASIA. RECENT EXPLORATIONS AND SUBSEQUENT RESEARCH HAVE IDENTIFIED GANASPIS BRASILIENSIS, A LARVAL PARASITOID, AS ONE OF THE MOST EFFICIENT AND HOST-SPECIFIC SWD PARASITOIDS. IN ADDITIONTO BIOLOGICAL CONTROL OPTIONS, PROMISING NEW BEHAVIORAL MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES, INCLUDING REPELLENTS, ATTRACT AND KILL AND BAIT METHODS ARE IN DEVELOPMENT. THESE STRATEGIES ARE REDUCED RISK COMPARED TO THE CURRENT INSECTICIDE USAGE. CURRENTLY, LITTLE IS KNOWN IF G. BRASILIENSIS WILL SUCCESSFULLY ESTABLISH, OVERWINTER, OR BE COMPATIBLE WITH NEW BEHAVIORAL MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. WE PROPOSE TO FURTHER OUR KNOWLEDGE ON THE ESTABLISHMENT, OVERWINTERING SUCCESS, AND CONSERVATION OF G. BRASILIENSIS THROUGH INTEGRATION WITH BEHAVIORAL MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES.

THIS IS A MULTI-STATE/MULTI-REGIONAL, APPLIED (SINGLE-FUNCTION) RESEARCH-LED PROPOSAL ADDRESSING THE PLANT PROTECTION TACTICS AND TOOLS CPPM FOCUS AREA. THERE IS A GROWING DEMAND FOR HEMP-DERIVED PRODUCTS IN THE UNITED STATES (US). RECENT ESTIMATES SUGGEST THAT HEMP PRODUCT SALES IN THE US ARE VALUED AT $700 MILLION. BECAUSE OF THE CROP'S PREVIOUS DESIGNATION AS A SCHEDULE 1 SUBSTANCE AND HISTORY OF CRIMINALIZATION, THERE IS LIMITED UNIVERSITY-PRODUCED INFORMATION DESCRIBING BEST PRODUCTION PRACTICES, WHICH INCLUDES INTEGRATED WEED MANAGEMENT (IWM). OUR GOALS ARE 1) DESCRIBE THE COMPETITIVENESS OF GRAIN, FIBER, AND FLORAL HEMP WITH WEEDS, 2) EVALUATE THE EFFICACY AND SAFETY OF INTEGRATED WEED MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN THIS EMERGING CROP, AND 3) DEVELOP AND DISSEMINATE EXTENSION MATERIALS. SPECIFICALLY, WE PROPOSE STUDIES, WHICH WILL BE CONDUCTED IN NY, VA, SC, IL, AND ND, TO DEFINE THE CRITICAL TIMING OF WEED MANAGEMENT OPERATIONS AGAINST COMMON AND TROUBLESOME WEEDS AND DESCRIBE THE IMPACTS OF CHEMICAL, PHYSICAL, AND CULTURAL PRACTICES ON THE SUPPRESSION OF UNWANTED VEGETATION. RESULTS FROM ROBUST AND REPLICATED STUDIES WILL BE SHARED WITH LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL STAKEHOLDERS TO REDUCE THE KNOWLEDGE GAP THAT CURRENTLY EXISTS FOR THIS ANCIENT, YET EMERGING, COMMODITY. ULTIMATE OUTCOMES OF THIS WORK INCLUDE INCREASED GROWER KNOWLEDGE REGARDING IWM IN HEMP, ALTERED PRODUCTION PRACTICES, AND ENHANCED AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTIVITY. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS THE CPPM GOAL OF SUSTAINABLE FOOD SECURITY THROUGH THE IMPROVEMENT OF IWM PRACTICES THAT INCREASES IPM ADOPTION AND REDUCES ENVIRONMENTAL AND HUMAN HEALTH RISKS WHILE SUPPORTING FARMER PROFITABILITY.

POTATO RANKS FOURTH AMONG THE WORLD'S MOST CONSUMED CROPS, WITH IDAHO ACCOUNTING FOR ABOUT 30% OF THE ACREAGE IN THE US AND MORE THAN HALF OF THE COUNTRY'S PROCESSED POTATO PRODUCTS. POTATO VIRUS Y (PVY) IS THE MOST IMPORTANT VIRUS AFFECTING POTATO, REDUCING YIELD AND QUALITY, ESPECIALLY IN THE SEED CROP. NUMEROUS APHID SPECIES TRANSMIT PVY TO POTATO, AND INSECTICIDES REMAIN A MAJOR COMPONENT OF PVY MANAGEMENT, DESPITE THEIR LIMITED UTILITY GIVEN THE SPEED OF VIRUS TRANSMISSION TO PLANTS. IMPROVEMENTS IN PVY MANAGEMENT ARE NEEDED, AND INCORPORATION OF CROP OILS IN CONJUNCTION WITH INSECTICIDES INTO INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT (IPM) PROGRAMS REPRESENTS AN OPTION THAT REMAINS POORLY STUDIED IN THE PNW.DECADES OF RESEARCH IN OTHER GROWING AREAS HAS DEMONSTRATED THE UTILITY OF CROP OIL SPRAYS IN REDUCING THE SPREAD OF VIRUSES LIKE PVY, ESPECIALLY WHEN APPLIED IN COMBINATION WITH INSECTICIDES. HOWEVER, CONCERNS REGARDING THE EFFECTS OF OVERHEAD IRRIGATION (USED ON NEARLY ALL OF THE PNW POTATO ACREAGE) ON PERSISTENCE OF CROP OILS ON FOLIAGE HAS LIMITED INTEREST IN CROP OILS IN THE PNW. LIMITED RESEARCH SUGGESTS THAT CROP OILS DO HAVE PROMISE IN THE PNW, BUT THIS NEEDS TO BE VERIFIED BEFORE THE PRACTICE CAN BE RECOMMENDED TO GROWERS. THIS PROJECT OUTLINES RESEARCH AIMED AT EVALUATING THE EFFICACY OF CROP OIL WITH AND WITHOUT INSECTICIDES IN MANAGING CURRENT-SEASON SPREAD OF PVY IN POTATO UNDER IDAHO FIELD CONDITIONS. MOREOVER, FIELD STUDIES WILL FOCUS ON MONITORING APHIDS IN POTATO SEED FIELDS IN ORDER TO DETERMINE THE OPTIMAL TIMING FOR APPLYING CROP OIL SPRAYS OR OTHER CONTROL MEASURES AGAINST APHIDS. FINALLY, GREENHOUSE ASSAYS WILL ASSESS HOW OVERHEAD IRRIGATION INFLUENCES THE EFFECTS OF CROP OILS ON APHID TRANSMISSION OF PVY.

SINCE THE 2013 INVASION OF THE SUGARCANE APHID (SCA) ON SORGHUM IN THE UNITED STATES, IPM SCIENTISTS AND PRACTITIONERS HAVE WORKED TOGETHER TO DEVELOP IPM PROGRAMS IN A DIVERSE SET OF GROWING REGIONS. IN THE SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL PLAINS, WHERE NEARLY 80% OF GRAIN SORGHUM IS GROWN, IPM PROGRAMS ARE CURRENTLY BASED ON DEPLOYMENT OF VARIETAL RESISTANCE, RELIABLE APHID ECONOMIC THRESHOLDS, EFFICIENT SAMPLING PLANS, AND CONSERVATION OF NATURAL ENEMIES THROUGH JUDICIOUS USE OF INSECTICIDES. A FINAL MISSING COMPONENT IS THE INTEGRATION OF NATURAL ENEMY THRESHOLDS INTO SCA MANAGEMENT PLANS. OUR RESEARCH AND EXTENSION TEAM WILL VALIDATE AND REFINE PRELIMINARY NE THRESHOLDS FOR SCA IN SORGHUM AT THE WHOLE-FIELD LEVEL IN A DIVERSE SET OF GROWING CONDITIONS THROUGHOUT THE REGION, INTEGRATE APHID AND NE SAMPLING PLANS, AND DELIVER AND EVALUATE THE ADOPTION OF THESE PLANS IN THE US SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL PLAINS. WE ANTICIPATE THAT A LARGE PERCENTAGE OF PRODUCERS AND IPM PRACTITIONERS WILL UTILIZE NE+SCA THRESHOLDS IN GRAIN SORGHUM. WIDESPREAD USE OF THESE NEWLY AVAILABLE COMBINED THRESHOLDS AGAINST THE INVASIVE SCA WILL ENHANCE SUSTAINABLE SORGHUM PRODUCTION.

MOST OF THE CORN AND COTTON GROWN IN THE US, EXPRESSES BT TOXINS DESIGNED TO KILL MAJOR INSECT PESTS. THE US CATEGORIZES BT TOXINS AS "PUBLIC GOODS" AT RISK OF BEING LOST DUE TO RESISTANCE. CORN GROWERS ARE REQUIRED TO PLANT 20% OF THEIR TOTAL CORN ACRES TO NON-BT (REFUGE) CORN TO DELAY THE EVOLUTION OF BT RESISTANCE. HOWEVER, VERY FEW GROWERS PLANT NON-BT CORN, PRIMARILY BECAUSE INSECTICIDE SUSCEPTIBILITY IS A COMMON POOL RESOURCE. PRIOR RESEARCH FROM OUR GROUP HAS SHOWN THAT MAJOR SEED COMPANIES HAVE HIGH-YIELDING NON-BT HYBRIDS AVAILABLE. OUR PROPOSAL WILL DEMONSTRATE THE YIELD POTENTIAL OF THESE NON-BT HYBRIDS PAIRED WITH CLOSELY RELATED BT HYBRIDS. WE WILL DO THIS ON 45 FARMS AND IN 13 OFFICIAL VARIETY TESTING FOR EACH OF TWO YEARS ACROSS NORTH CAROLINA AND VIRGINIA. WE WILL ALSO TRAIN COOPERATIVE EXTENSION AGENTS ON GENERAL CORN AGRONOMY AND HOW TO IDENTIFY INSECT DAMAGE SO THAT THEY CAN COLLECT DATA. THIS DATA WILL FEED INTO A DAMAGE ABATEMENT MODEL TO ESTIMATE THE SHORT RUN-IMPACTS OF NON-BT HYBRIDS, AS WELL AS A LONG-RUN ECONOMIC ANALYSIS TO ACCOUNT FOR THE DIFFERENCE IN THE EVOLUTION OF RESISTANCE WHEN PLANTING NON-BT HYBRIDS. FINALLY, THIS INFORMATION WILL BE DISTRIBUTED TO STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH PUBLICATION ON THE NORTH CAROLINA COOPERATIVE EXTENSION CORN PORTAL, PRESENTATIONS IN COUNTY WINTER MEETINGS, AND THROUGH INCORPORATION INTO THE VARIETY SELECTION TOOL DATABASE. GROWERS USE THIS TOOL TO SELECT HYBRIDS APPROPRIATE FOR THEIR FARM BASED ON DATA GATHERED FROM NC OFFICIAL VARIETY TRIALS PLANTED IN MULTIPLE LOCATIONS ACROSS NORTH CAROLINA.

HIGH COSTS FOR WEED CONTROL AND YIELD LOSS FROM SOIL-BORNE DISEASES ARE SEVERE THREATS TO CHILE PEPPER PRODUCTION IN THE UNITED STATES SOUTHWEST. TO ADDRESS THESE THREATS TO CHILE PEPPER, WE WILL DEVELOP ECOLOGICALLY-BASED TACTICS THAT TARGET BOTH WEEDS AND SOIL-BORNE PATHOGENS. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL ESTABLISH OPTIMUM MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR BARLEY AND MUSTARD COVER CROPS THAT ARE INCORPORATED INTO SOIL SHORTLY BEFORE CHILE PEPPER SEEDING. BASED ON OUR PRELIMINARY STUDIES AND REPORTS IN LITERATURE, WE EXPECT THAT OPTIMALLY MANAGED MUSTARD AND BARLEY COVER CROPS WILL SUPPRESS WEED EMERGENCE, REDUCE REQUIREMENTS FOR HAND HOEING, AND ACCELERATE MORTALITY IN WEED SEEDBANKS. WE ALSO ANTICIPATE THAT OPTIMALLY MANAGED MUSTARD AND BARLEY COVER CROPS WILL SUPPRESS PROPAGULE PERSISTENCE AND GROWTH OF SOIL-BORNE PATHOGENS, AND INHIBIT INFECTION ON CHILE PEPPER PLANTS BY SOIL-BORNE PATHOGENS. IN ADDITION TO DETERMINING THE EXTENT OF COVER CROP-INDUCED REDUCTIONS IN WEEDS AND SOIL-BORNE DISEASES,WE WILL CONDUCT COST-BENEFIT ANALYSES THAT WILL CLARIFY THE ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF MUSTARD AND BARLEY COVER CROPS. THESE COST-BENEFIT ANALYSES WILL BE PRESENTED TO FARMERS DURING OUTREACH EVENTS. WITH KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM THIS STUDY, FARMERS WILL BE ABLE TO EFFECTIVELY UTILIZE AN INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT TACTIC THAT IMPROVES PROFITABILITY BY DIMINISHING PESTICIDE AND HAND LABOR REQUIREMENTS IN CHILE PEPPER.

APPLES ARE ONE OF THE TOPMOST CONSUMED FRUIT IN THE UNITED STATES, SECOND IN POPULARITY ONLY TO BANANAS. THEY HAVE AN ANNUAL FARM-GATE VALUE OF NEARLY US$4 BILLION, WITH DOWNSTREAM REVENUES EXCEEDING US$15 BILLION. APPLES ARE AVAILABLE AND ENJOYED YEAR-ROUND BECAUSE THEY CAN BE HELD IN COLD STORAGE UNDER CONTROLLED ATMOSPHERE CONDITIONS, WHICH SUSPENDS THE RIPENING PROCESS SUCH THAT AN APPLE MAINTAINS ITS CRISPNESS AND TASTE 9-11 MONTHS AFTER THEY WERE HARVESTED. POSTHARVEST ROT DURING STORAGE CAUSED BY FUNGAL PATHOGENS IS A PERSISTENT THREAT TO THE GLOBAL US APPLE INDUSTRY. THIS NOT ONLY REDUCES THEIR QUALITY, INCREASES FOOD LOSS, BUT ALSO CAN LEAD TO MYCOTOXIN CONTAMINATION OF PROCESSED FRUIT PRODUCTS. ANNUAL LOSSES DUE TO POSTHARVEST ROTS RANGE BETWEEN 1%-15% IN THE UNITED STATES, ALONE. CURRENT ESTIMATES OF THE ECONOMIC LOSSES DUE TO POSTHARVEST APPLE ROTS ARE NOT AVAILABLE; HOWEVER, ESTIMATING 15% LOSS OF THE 4.5-5 MILLION TONNES OF APPLES PRODUCED ANNUALLY IN THE UNITED STATES, AND AN AVERAGE PRICE OF US$1.5 PER POUND, UP TO US$2.5 BILLION ARE LOST EACH YEAR DUE TO POSTHARVEST ROTS. APPROXIMATELY A DOZEN DISEASES CAN AFFECT APPLES DURING STORAGE. THE MOST FREQUENT POSTHARVEST ROTS OF APPLES ARE BLUE MOLD, CAUSED BY PENICILLIUM EXPANSUM AND OTHER PENICILLIUM SPP., AND GRAY MOLD, CAUSED BY BOTRYTIS CINEREA. THE FUNGI CAUSING BLUE MOLD ARE OF MOST CONCERN SINCE SEVERAL OF THE SPECIES PRODUCE THE MYCOTOXIN PATULIN. UNFORTUNATELY, NO APPLE VARIETIES EXIST THAT ARE RESISTANT TO THESE DISEASES AND MANAGEMENT OPTIONS OF POSTHARVEST APPLE ROT ARE LIMITED. GROWERS RELY ON CONTINUED USE OF SYNTHETIC FUNGICIDES, WHICH THERE ARE FEW AND HAVE CAUSED THE EMERGENCE OF FUNGICIDE RESISTANT STRAINS IN APPLE PACKINGHOUSES IN THE UNITED STATES. THIS REDUCES THEIR UTILITY AS CONTROL OPTIONS IN STORAGE SINCE FUNGICIDE FAILURE IS MORE LIKELY TO OCCUR. CONSIDERING CONSUMERS DEMAND APPLES WITH LESS PESTICIDE RESIDUES AND COMMERCIAL APPLE CULTIVARS LACK RESISTANCE TO MOST OF THE POSTHARVEST PATHOGENS NEW INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT OPTIONS ARE NECESSARY.POSTHARVEST APPLE DISEASE RESEARCH HAS BEEN LIMITED TO WASHINGTON AND OREGON, DEMONSTRATING STORAGE BINS, DUMP TANK WATER, AND THE AIR OF THE PACKINGHOUSE FACILITIES AND COLD ROOMS HARBOR HIGH LEVELS OF ROT PATHOGENS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO POSTHARVEST DECAY, WITH PENICILLIUM SPP. AS THE PREDOMINANT FUNGUS. TO ERADICATE PATHOGENS, TREATING BIN SURFACES WITH STEAM, CLEANING PACKINGHOUSE WALLS AND FLOORS WITH DISINFECTANTS, AND MAINTAINING PROPER CHLORINE LEVELS IN SIZING FLUMES HAVE BEEN RECOMMENDED. IT IS UNKNOWN IF THE WESTERN U.S. RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS CAN BE EXTRAPOLATED TO MEET THE NEEDS FOR MID-ATLANTIC APPLE GROWERS AND PACKERS, WHO PRODUCE APPROXIMATELY 760 MILLION POUNDS OF APPLES ANNUALLY. CONSEQUENTLY, THESE PRACTICES ARE NOT ROUTINELY IMPLEMENTED IN APPLE PACKINGHOUSES LOCATED IN THE MID-ATLANTIC REGION DUE TO THE ECONOMIC COST AND THE LACK OF REGION-SPECIFIC RESEARCH DEMONSTRATING THEIR EFFICACY ONREDUCING THE INCIDENCE AND SEVERITY OF POSTHARVEST ROTS. THERE IS AN EXPRESSED NEED FOR RESEARCH AND OPTIMIZED POSTHARVEST DISEASE MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS, INCLUDING IDENTIFYING ALTERNATIVES TO SYNTHETIC POSTHARVEST FUNGICIDES, GEARED TOWARDS MID-ATLANTIC APPLE GROWERS AND PACKERS. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO FILL A MAJOR GAP IN KNOWLEDGE FOR POSTHARVEST APPLE DISEASES AND APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR THE MID-ATLANTIC. WE WILL ACCOMPLISH THIS BY IDENTIFYNG THE FUNGI CAUSING POSTHARVEST APPLE ROTS IN PENNSYLVANIA AND MARYLAND PACKINGHOUSES AND DETERMINE THE SOURCE OF WHERE THE FUNGAL SPORES ORIGINATE. IN ADDITION, WE WILL CONCURRENTLY BE EVALUATING THE STATUS OF FUNGICIDE RESISTANCE AMONG THE FUNGAL PATHOGENS COLLECTED AGAINST THE FOUR POSTHARVEST FUNGICIDES USED. STUDIES WILL INVESTIGATE IF WOODEN AND PLASTIC BINS SERVE AS A VIABLE PATHOGEN SOURCE FOR ROTS, AS DESCRIBED IN WESTERN APPLE PACKHOUSES. CURRENT METHODS, SUCH AS STEAM, AND NEW TOOLS AND DELIVERY SYSTEMS, SUCH AS FOGGING, AND ORGANIC CONTROLS WILL BE EVALUATED FOR SANITIZING BINS AND/OR OTHER SURFACES, AS WELL AS USED TO LIMIT POSTHARVEST APPLE DECAY. SCIENCE-BASED INFORMATION WILL BE COMMUNICATED TO STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH EXTENSION PROGRAMMING BOTH IN ENGLISH AND SPANISH FOR OPTIMIZED CHEMICAL AND CULTURAL POSTHARVEST DISEASE MANAGEMENT PROTOCOLS. RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT ARE EXPECTED TO BE TRANSFORMATIVE AND IMPACTFUL TO MANY APPLE PRODUCING AREAS HAVING SIMILAR PRODUCTION PRACTICES SUCH AS NEW ENGLAND, NEW YORK, MICHIGAN, THE MIDWEST, AND SOUTHEAST REGIONS. THROUGH THE METHODS DESCRIBED, THE ULTIMATE GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE UNDERSTANDING THE STATUS OF POSTHARVEST APPLE DISEASES AND DEVELOPING TAILORED, COST-EFFECTIVE, SUSTAINABLE DISEASE MANAGEMENT FOR CONVENTIONAL AND ORGANIC MID-ATLANTIC APPLE GROWERS AND PACKERS. ADOPTION OF OPTIMIZED POSTHARVEST DISEASE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES WILL BE ECONOMICAL FOR THE STAKEHOLDERS RESULTING IN LESS CROP LOSS WHILE REDUCING HUMAN HEALTH RISKS THROUGH LIMITING EXPOSURE OF FRUIT CONTAMINATED WITH MYCOTOXINS AND MYCOTOXIN-PRODUCING FUNGI.

THIS RESEARCH-LED PROJECT ADDRESSES THE CPPM FOCUS AREA (1) OF PLANT PROTECTION TACTICS AND TOOLS AND AIMS TO DEVELOP ADEQUATE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AGAINST GAY MOLD, CAUSED BY BOTRYTIS CINEREA, ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT DISEASES OF APPLE AND PEAR IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST. RECENT REGIONAL LARGE SURVEYS REVEALED GRAY MOLD AS THE MOST IMPORTANT STORAGE DISEASE BESIDE BLUE MOLD. INFECTIONS BY B. CINEREA OCCUR IN THE ORCHARDS BUT BECAUSE OF THE PERCEPTION THAT GRAY MOLD IS A STORAGE PROBLEM, PREHARVEST MANAGEMENT IS OFTEN DELAYED TO THE LAST TWO WEEKS BEFORE HARVEST OR AFTER HARVEST. THE DEARTH OF KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE EPIDEMIOLOGY OF BOTRYTIS IN APPLE AND PEAR IN THE PNW AND ELSEWHERE RENDERED CURRENT MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES INEFFECTIVE. MOREOVER, BECAUSE NONE OF THE CURRENT APPLE OR PEAR CULTIVARS IS RESISTANT TO B. CINEREA, MANAGEMENT RELIES SOLELY ON FUNGICIDE APPLICATIONS WHICH DIFFER BETWEEN THE VARIOUS GROWING REGIONS IN THE PNW. WHETHER THE RECENT SURGE IN GRAY MOLD IS DUE TO THE EMERGENCE OF RESISTANCE TO FUNGICIDES, IN USE FOR MORE THAN THREE DECADES, REMAINS UNKNOWN. OUR PROJECT GOALS ARE TO PROVIDE THE POME FRUIT INDUSTRIES WITH: (1) EPIDEMIOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE TO AID GROWERS AND PACKERS IN GRAY MOLD MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, (2) REGIONAL DOCUMENTATION OF FUNGICIDE RESISTANCE LEVELS TO SUPPORT MID- AND LONG-TERM CONTROL, (3) EPIDEMIOLOGY-BASED AND IMPROVED MANAGEMENT TACTICS PERTINENT IN VARIOUS PRODUCTION AREAS, (4) ECONOMIC ANALYSIS TOOLS TO INCREASE PROFITABILITY OF STAKEHOLDERS, AND (5) CONTINUE REGIONAL AND NATIONAL EXTENSION EFFORTS TO EDUCATE POME FRUIT GROWERS ABOUT GRAY MOLD BEST MANAGEMENT TACTICS.

THE CONTINUING RISE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF HERBICIDE-RESISTANT WEEDS DRIVES THE NEED FOR INTEGRATED WEED MANAGEMENT (IWM) TACTICS TO PRESERVE CROP YIELDS AND MAKE MORE JUDICIOUS USE OF HERBICIDES. THE USE OF COVER CROPS IS ONE TOOL IN THE IWM ARSENAL. HOWEVER, IWM IN GENERAL AND THE USE OF COVER CROPS SPECIFICALLY HAVE NOT BEEN WIDELY ADOPTED, LARGELY BECAUSE THE COMPLEXITY OF INTERACTIONS AMONG COVER CROPS, CLIMATE, SOIL, MANAGEMENT, AND WEEDS IS DAUNTING AND MAKES IWM A TIME-CONSUMING TASK. WE PROPOSE ON-FARM RESEARCH AT MANY SITES ACROSS A WIDE LATITUDINAL GRADIENT TO DEFINE AND COVER CROP MANAGEMENT BY ENVIRONMENT IMPACTS ON WEEDS TO IMPROVE THE PRECISION OF COVER CROPS AS AN IWM TOOL BY CREATING LITERAL MANAGEMENT IWM DECISION TOOLS THAT REDUCE COMPLEXITY FOR FARMERS. IN DOING SO WE AIM TO INCREASE THE ADOPTION OF COVER CROPS AS AN IWM PRACTICE AND TO IMPROVE THE USE OF IWM IN GENERAL BY MAKING IT EASIER FOR FARMERS TO TARGET (AND THUS REDUCE) HERBICIDE APPLICATIONS WHILE REALIZING ANCILLARY BENEFITS OF COVER CROPS (E.G. REDUCED SOIL EROSION, NUTRIENT LOSS, ETC.). THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS THE ULTIMATE CPPM GOAL OF SUSTAINABLE FOOD SECURITY THROUGH THE IMPROVEMENT OF IWM PRACTICES (I.E. INCLUSION OF COVER CROPS IN CROPPING SYSTEMS TO MANAGE WEEDS) THAT INCREASES IPM ADOPTION (I.E. USE OF NON-HERBICIDE METHODS OF WEED CONTROL) AND REDUCES ENVIRONMENTAL AND HUMAN HEALTH RISKS (I.E. VIA DECREASED HERBICIDE APPLICATION) WHILE SUPPORTING FARMER PROFITABILITY.

BRETZIELLA FAGACEARUM IS A FUNGAL PLANT PATHOGEN THAT CAUSES OAK WILT DISEASE IN MANY ECOLOGICALLY AND ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT OAK TREE SPECIES. SYMPTOMS OF OAK WILT ARE EASILY CONFUSED WITH DROUGHT STRESS AND OTHER BACTERIAL DISEASES THAT ARE VECTORED BY INSECT LEAFHOPPERS. EFFORTS TO MAP U.S. OCCURRENCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF OAK WILT HAVE BEEN COMPLICATED BY THE SIMILAR APPEARANCE OF CONSEQUENCES TO OAK OF THESE DIFFERENT BIOTIC AND ABIOTIC STRESSORS. IN THE URBAN LANDSCAPE AND NURSERY, INACCURATE DISEASE DIAGNOSIS CAN LEAD TO OVER-RELIANCE ON CHEMICAL PESTICIDES AND USE OF INEFFECTIVE TREATMENTS APPLIED TO CONTROL THE WRONG PROBLEM. THIS CONFUSION ALSO HAS RESULTED IN COMPLICATIONS FOR U.S. AGRICULTURE AND EXPORT COMMODITIES. HARVESTED LOGS INTENDED FOR INTERNATIONAL EXPORT ARE SUBJECT TO QUARANTINE WHEN ORIGINATING FROM LOCATIONS WITHIN THE U.S. WHERE OAK WILT IS DOCUMENTED. LOGS FROM THESE AREAS MUST BE PROVIDED PHYTOSANITARY TREATMENTS IN ORDER FOR EXPORT TO PROCEED. PENDING WITHDRAWAL OF THE PHYTOSANITARY FUMIGANT METHYL BROMIDE POTENTIALLY WILL RESULT IN LOSS OF ACCESS TO SOME EUROPEAN AND ASIAN MARKETS FOR AGROFORESTRY OAK LOGS.THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE NEW INSIGHTS INTO THE HOST PLANT GENES THAT ARE ACTIVATED ACROSS TIME, AS A NATURAL METHOD OF HOST PLANT DEFENSE IN WHITE OAK AND RED OAK TREE SEEDLINGS, WHEN SUBJECTED TO INFECTION BY WITH THE OAK WILT PATHOGEN. EFFORTS WILL ALSO DOCUMENT THE GENES UP-REGULATED WITHIN A MOST VIRULENT AND A LEAST VIRULENT ISOLATE OF THE FUNGAL PATHOGEN WHEN ATTACKING TWO OAK HOST SPECIES, AS THE PATHOGEN SEEKS TO OVERCOME THE HOST PLANT DEFENSES. TAKEN TOGETHER, NEW SCIENCE ARISING FROM THESE EXPERIMENTS WILL PROVIDE NOVEL INSIGHTS INTO HOST PLANT RESISTANCE THAT CAN INFORM FUTURE TREE BREEDING IN OAKS THAT YIELDS GREATER STRENGTH AND SUSTAINABILITY FOR THIS HIGHLY VALUED U.S. FOREST SPECIES AND AGRICULTURAL CROP COMMODITY. LASTLY, THIS RESEARCH COMPLIMENTS THE PARTICIPATING TEAM'S ONGOING EFFORTS TO DEVELOP A RAPID MOLECULAR TEST TO FACILITATE OAK WILT DIAGNOSIS AND DETECTION IN LANDSCAPE TREES, FOREST SPECIMENS, AND HARVESTED LOGS INTENDED FOR INTERNATIONAL EXPORT. IN COMBINATION, THESE APPROACHES ARE EXPECTED TO PROVIDE POWERFUL NEW TOOLS IN EFFORTS TO DELINEATE REGIONAL OCCURRENCE OF OAK WILT AND TO PREVENT ITS SPREAD INTO NEW, UNINFESTED LOCATIONS AROUND THE GLOBE.

THIS PROJECT WILL GENERATE GENETIC MARKERS THAT CAN REVEAL IF INDIVIDUAL SOYBEAN APHIDS ARE RESISTANT TO PYRETHROIDS. THIS IS IMPORTANT BECAUSE THIS INSECT HAS DEVELOPED RESISTANCE TO THIS CLASS OF INSECTICIDE IN THE MIDWEST, WHERE THE MAJORITY OF SOYBEANS ARE GROWN IN THE US. PYRETHROIDS ARE IMPORTANT BECAUSE THEY ARE CHEAP AND CONSIDERED EFFECTIVE IN PREVENTING OUTBREAKS OF THE SOYBEAN APHID. UNFORTUNATELY, THIS IS NO LONGER TRUE FOR A GROWING REGION OF THE MIDWEST.FARMERS RISK LOSING YIELD AND PROFIT FROM RESISTANCE IN TWO WAYS. FIRST,YIELD IS LOST AS APHIDS CONTINUE TO FEED AFTER THE APPLICATION OF A PYRETHROID TO A FIELD INFESTED WITH A RESISTANT POPULATION. SECOND, SWITCHING TO ANOTHER INSECTICIDE (E.G., AFIDOPRYROPEN, FLONICAMID, PYMETROZINE, SPIROTETRAMAT, AND SULFLOXAFLOR) IS MORE EXPENSIVE. CLOSE IN COST TO LAMBDA-CYHALOTHRIN (THE MOST COMMONLY USED PYRETHROID, AT A COST OF $6.22 PER ACRE) IS CHLORPYRIFOS($9.22 PER ACRE), PER A RECENT SURVEY OF AGRIBUSINESSES IN IOWA. HOWEVER, CHLORPYRIFOS MAY BE RESTRICTED OR HAVE IT'S REGISTRATION CANCELLED IN THE NEAR FUTURE, REQUIRING FARMERS TO APPLY EVEN MORE EXPENSIVE OPTIONS FOR MANAGING PYRETHROID-RESISTANT SOYBEAN APHIDS. FARMERS WITH NO PRIOR EXPERIENCE DEALING WITH PYRETHROID-RESISTANT SOYBEAN APHIDS COULD SUFFER BOTH FORMS OF LOSS IN THE SAME YEAR IF NOT PROVIDED DATA TO ADEQUATELY MANAGE AN OUTBREAK.THIS LOSS CAN BE PREVENTED IF FARMERS ARE INFORMED ABOUT THE PROBABILITY OF AN OUTBREAK CONTAINING PYRETHROID-RESISTANT APHIDS. WE WILL DEVELOP MARKERS TO IDENTIFY WHICH APHIDS ARE RESISTANT TO PYRETHROIDS. WE WILL DEMONSTRATE TO FARMERS AND AGRIBUSINESS HOW THESE MARKERS CAN BE USED BEFORE AND AFTER AN INSECTICIDE APPLICATION TO DETERMINE IF AN OUTBREAK WAS PREVENTED. WE WILL INCORPORATE THESE DATA INTO ECONOMIC MODELS TO INFORM FARMERS ABOUT THE NEED TO ADJUST THIER MANAGEMENT TO MAXIMIXE PROFIT. THESE EXPERIMENTS WILL BE SUMMARIZED IN AN EXTENSION PROGRAM USING MULTIPLE WAYS TO COMMUNICATE TO A DIVERSE AUDIENCE (PODCASTS, TWITTER, FIELD DAYS).RESEARCH RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT CAN HELP PRODUCERS PREVENT THE LOSS OF $67 PER ACRE THAT OCCURS WHEN INSECTICIDE RESISTANT APHIDS ARE NOT PROPERLY MANAGED. THIS BENEFIT IS BASED ON THE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW TOOL FOR FARMERS AND AGRIBUSINESS TO USE IN THE MANAGEMENT OF INSECTICIDE-RESISTANT APHIDS.

THE DIAMONDBACK MOTH, PLUTELLA XYLOSTELLA, IS A NOTORIOUS PEST OF COLE AND OTHER BRASSICA CROPS. IT IS ALSO KNOWN FOR THE RAPID EVOLUTION OF RESISTANCE TO INSECTICIDES, AND IS LIKELY RESISTANT TO A BROADER ARRAY OF INSECTICIDES THAN ANY OTHER CROP PEST. IN THE SOUTHEASTERN USA, THIS HAS LED TO FREQUENT CONTROL FAILURES AND ASSOCIATED LOSS OF REVENUE FOR GROWERS. IN THE PREVIOUS CYCLE, WE DEVELOPED A MAXIMUM DOSE ASSAY TO ASSIST GROWERS IN PLANNING INSECTICIDE ROTATIONS. THIS ASSAY EXPOSES LARVAE TO THE MAXIMUM LABELED DOSE OF A VARIETY OF INSECTICIDES; IF LARVAE SURVIVE THE EXPOSURE IN SIGNIFICANT NUMBERS USE OF THE INSECTICIDE IS COUNTER-INDICATED. A CONSTRAINT OF THE ASSAY IS THE NEED FOR A SIGNIFICANT NUMBER OF LARVAE. THE CURRENT STUDY SEEKS TO DEVELOP GENETIC TOOLS, PARTICULARLY QUANTITATIVE PCR ASSAYS, TO DETERMINE THE PREVALENCE OF ALLELES (OR MUTATIONS) ASSOCIATED WITH RESISTANCE, INITIALLY TO CHLORANTRANILIPROLE (CORAGEN) AND LATER TO OTHER INSECTICIDES. IDEALLY THESE ASSAYSCAN BE RAPID AND WORK WITH SMALLER SAMPLE SIZES OF LARVAE, OR WITH ADULTS CAUGHT ON PHEROMONE TRAPS, PROVIDING TIMELY INFORMATION TO GROWERS PLANNING THEIR INSECTICIDE ROTATIONS.INITIALLY WE WILL FOCUS ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF SENSITIVE AND SPECIFIC PCR ASSAYS TO QUANTIFY THE PROPORTION OF SUSCEPTIBLE AND RESISTANT ALLELES IN FIELD POPULATIONS. COMPARISON OF THE RESULTS WITH BIOASSAY RESULTS FROM THE SAME POPULATIONS WILL ALLOW US TO DEVELOP A PREDICTIVE MODEL RELATING ALLELE FREQUENCY TO THE LIKELIHOOD OF CONTROL FAILURE. SUBSEQUENTLY, THE ASSAY WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO GROWERS AND EXTENSION AGENTS TO ASSIST IN PLANNING INSECTICIDE ROTATIONS AND IN MANAGING TO AVOID INSECTICIDE RESISTANCE.ALTHOUGH THE PLANNED DIAGNOSTIC ASSAYS WILL EXPLOIT KNOWN MUTATIONS ASSOCIATED WITH RESISTANCE, THERE IS MUCH THAT IS STILL UNCLEAR ABOUT RESISTANCE TO DIAMIDES (AND OTHER CLASSES OF INSECTICIDES FOR THAT MATTER). WE WILL USE HIGH THROUGHPUT MRNA/CDNA SEQUENCING AND TRANSCRIPTOMIC ANALYSIS TO STUDY THE RESPONSE TO DIAMIDE (CHLORTRANILIPROLE AND CYANTRANILIPROLE) EXPOSURE IN SUSCEPTIBLE AND RESISTANT POPULATIONS OF DIAMONDBACK MOTHS. THIS APPROACH IS LIKELY TO IDENTIFY MULTIPLE FACTORS INVOLVED IN RESISTANCE, INCLUDING UP-OR DOWN-REGULATION OF SPECIFIC TRANSCRIPTS AS WELL AS POTENTIALLY NOVEL MUTATIONS IN TARGET SITES. THIS MORE GLOBAL INDERSTANDING OF THE DIFFERENTIAL RESPONSE OF RESISTANT VS SUSCEPTIBLE POPULATIONS MAY LEAD TO NOVEL APPROACHES TO RESISTANCE MANAGEMENT.

ACCEPTABLE WEED CONTROL IN PLASTICULTURE VEGETABLE SYSTEMS CAN BE DIFFICULT. HERBICIDES ARE RELIED UPON HEAVILY FOR WEED CONTROL; HOWEVER, FEWER PRODUCTS ARE AVAILABLE IN VEGETABLE PRODUCTION COMPARED TO ROW CROPS SUCH AS CORN AND SOYBEAN. IN ADDITION, MANY WEED SPECIES HAVE DEVELOPED RESISTANCE TO THE FEW HERBICIDES AVAILABLE. NON-CHEMICAL OPTIONS, SUCH AS CULTIVATION AND HAND WEEDING CAN BE USED, BUT THESE CAN HAVE INCREASED ECONOMIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL COSTS. THIS CAN RESULT IN A NEGATIVE IMPACT ON THE OVERALL SUSTAINABILITY OF PLASTICULTURE CROPPING SYSTEMS.COVER CROPS ARE AN ALTERNATIVE WEED MANAGEMENT TOOL THAT HAS BEEN SUCCESSFULLY USED IN MULTIPLE CROPPING SYSTEMS. THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE UTILITY OF GRASS COVER CROPS PLANTED IN-BETWEEN ROWS OF PLASTIC CAN BE INTEGRATED WITH OTHER TACTICS FOR ACHIEVING ACCEPTABLE LEVELS OF WEED CONTROL. THE RESULTS OF THIS RESEARCH WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP INTEGRATED WEED MANAGEMENT METHODS FOR WEED CONTROL, WHICH WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE SUSTAINABILITY OF WEED MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS AND INCREASE PROFITABILITY IN VEGETABLE PRODUCTION SYSTEMS.

THERE HAVE BEEN IMPORTANT RECENT ADVANCES IN OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW TO CONTROL THE PRIORITY PEST CONCERNS FOR REGIONAL BLUEBERRY GROWERS, OFFERING POTENTIAL ALTERNATIVES TO THE CURRENT HIGH RATES OF INSECTICIDE APPLICATIONS THAT ARE FOCUSED ON KEY PESTS INCLUDING GALL WASP AND SPOTTED WING DROSOPHILA. WE WILL EVALUATE AND DEMONSTRATE EFFECTIVE IPM PROGRAMS, WHILE ALSO COMPARING THE RETURN ON INVESTMENT OF DIFFERENT APPROACHES. USE OF SCOUTING AND DEGREE-DAY MODELS IS EXPECTED TO BETTER INFORM SPRAY PROGRAM INITIATION, ALLOW LONGER SPRAY INTERVALS, AND ALLOW TARGETED SPRAYING ON AREAS OF THE FARM. ADDITIONALLY, MULCHING AND PRUNING HAVE BEEN SHOWN TO REDUCE PEST INFESTATION AND THEY WILL BE TESTED IN COMBINATION WITH REDUCED-RISK INSECTICIDE PROGRAMS. CONSERVATION BIOLOGICAL CONTROL AND TARGETED USE OF NEMATODES ALSO SHOW PROMISE FOR REGULATING PEST LEVELS BELOW ECONOMIC THRESHOLDS. WE WILL EVALUATE THESE APPROACHES AT COMMERCIAL BLUEBERRY FARMS TO DETERMINE THEIR POTENTIAL FOR IMPROVING FRUIT QUALITY, REDUCING PESTICIDE COSTS, AND LOWERING ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT AND WORKER RISK. SINCE ECONOMICS IS A CRITICAL COMPONENT OF IPM ADOPTION, THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO COMPARE THE COSTS AND BENEFITS OF DIFFERENT IPM COMPONENTS TO HIGHLIGHT THEIR RETURN-ON-INVESTMENT. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE INTEGRATED INTO OUR EXISTING BILINGUAL EXTENSION PROGRAMMING TO ADVANCE THE GOALS OF THE CPPM PROGRAM.

THIS IS AN APPLIED RESEARCH (SINGLE-FUNCTION) PROJECT WITH THE GOAL OF DEVELOPING AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE SPATIAL DYNAMICS OF SOYBEAN GALL MIDGE LARVAE UNDER FIELD CONDITIONS AND THE TEMPORAL OCCURRENCE OF LARVAE AND THEIR DEVELOPMENT STAGE OVER THE COURSE OF THE GROWING SEASON. SOYBEAN GALL MIDGE IS A NEWLY IDENTIFIED SPECIES, CAUSING SIGNIFICANT ECONOMIC LOSSES TO SOYBEAN IN NEBRASKA, IOWA, SOUTH DAKOTA, AND MINNESOTA. ITS RAPID DEVELOPMENT AS A NEW PEST HAS LEFT SIGNIFICANT GAPS IN KNOWLEDGE THAT ARE NEEDED TO IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO MITIGATE ITS INJURY. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE: (1) DETERMINE THE SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF SOYBEAN GALL MIDGE LARVAE IN A FIELD, WITHIN THE SOIL PROFILE, AND THEIR MOVEMENT FROM INFESTED PLANTS; (2) EVALUATE THE TEMPORAL OCCURRENCE AND DEVELOPMENT CHANGES OF SOYBEAN GALL MIDGE LARVAE, AND (3) DISSEMINATE INFORMATION TO ASSIST CLIENTELE WITH MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. TO DO THIS, WE WILL COLLECT SOIL SAMPLES FROM LOCATIONS WHERE SOYBEAN GALL MIDGE ADULTS ARE BEING MONITORED WITH EMERGENCE CAGES. TO TEST THE SPATIAL MOVEMENT OF LARVAE FROM INFESTED PLANTS, TARGETED PLANTINGS WILL BE MADE IN FIELDS WITH NO SOYBEAN FOR SIX METERS IN EITHER DIRECTION PERPENDICULAR TO THE SOYBEAN. THE RESULTS FROM THIS EXPERIMENT WILL PROVIDE CRITICAL UNDERLYING ECOLOGICAL INFORMATION ON THE TEMPORAL OCCURRENCE OF LARVAE IN SOYBEAN PLANTS AND THE SOIL RELATIVE TO ADULT ACTIVITY PERIODS. SUCH INFORMATION IS FUNDAMENTAL TO IDENTIFYING, IMPLEMENTING, AND UNDERSTANDING THE POTENTIAL OF CURRENT AND FUTURE PEST MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. THE OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE CLIENTELE WITH A BASELINE FOR IMPLEMENTING MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THROUGH A GREATER UNDERSTANDING OF THE SEASONAL ECOLOGY OF SOYBEAN GALL MIDGE AND ENHANCE THE ACCURACY OF ADULT EMERGENCE CAGES THAT SERVE AS THE BACKBONE FOR INITIATING CURRENT PEST MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. THE LONG TERM OUTCOMES ARE AN ECOLOGY CENTERED APPROACH TO MITIGATION AND MANAGEMENT OF SOYBEAN GALLMIDGE AS WELL AS THE DEVELOPMENT OF A BASELINE FOR FUTURE RESEARCH. THIS PROJECT DIRECTLY ADDRESSES THE PLANT PROTECTION TACTICS AND TOOLS AS WELL AS DIVERSIFIED IPM SYSTEMS FOCUS AREAS WITHIN THE APPLIED RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM AREA OF THE CROP PROTECTION AND PEST MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.

THIS IS AN ARDP RESEARCH (SINGLE-FUNCTION) MULTI-STATE, MULTI-INSTITUTIONAL PROJECT THAT AIMS TO IMPROVE ADOPTION OF PLANT PROTECTION TOOLS AND TACTICS (A) BY DEMONSTRATING HOW LONG-LASTING INSECTICIDE-INCORPORATED NETTING (LLIN) MAY SYNERGIZE EFFICACY OF PEST MANAGEMENT WHEN USED WITH A DIVERSIFIED SUITE OF OTHER MANAGEMENT TACTICS AT FOOD FACILITIES IN THE US. THIS IS PARTICULARLY IMPORTANT WITH THE LOSS OF THE MOST IMPORTANT FUMIGANT IN POSTPHARVEST PEST MANAGEMENT, METHYL BROMIDE, AS WELL AS INCREASING CHALLENGES WITH THE USE OF THE MOST COMMON REPLACEMENT, PHOSPHINE, INCLUDING WIDESPREAD DEVELOPMENT OF RESISTANCE AND INCREASING DEMAND BY END CONSUMERS FOR FEWER CHEMICAL INPUTS. OUR TEAM HAS DEMONSTRATED THAT LLIN IS EFFECTIVE, LONG-LASTING, AND CONFINES INSECTICIDE USE TO THE NETTING AND AWAY FROM THE COMMODITY. HOWEVER, WE PROPOSE TO SPEED ADOPTION BY 1) SYNERGIZING LLIN DEPLOYMENT TO IMPROVE PHOSPHINE FUMIGATION EFFICACY, 2) DEMONSTRATING COMPATIBILITY OF LLIN WITH AEROSOL USE, 3) IMPROVING MANAGEMENT OUTCOMES OF USING A NOVEL RESIDUAL CONTACT INSECTICIDE BY PAIRING WITH LLIN, AND 4) DEVELOPING ONLINE RESOURCES FOR STAKEHOLDERS AND ASSESSING ECONOMIC FEASIBILITY OF INCORPORATING LLIN INTO MANAGEMENT. OUR PROJECT COVERS THE MOST COMMON PEST MANAGEMENT TACTICS USED AT FOOD FACILITIES, AND SHOULD DEMONSTRATE THAT LLIN IS NOT JUST COMPATIBLE WITH EXISTING IPM PROGRAMS, BUT WILL VASTLY IMPROVE THEIR EFFICACY. IN TURN, THIS WILL SPEED TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER AND ADOPTION OF LLIN TECHNOLOGY BY FOOD FACILITIES. OUR PROPOSAL INCLUDES PERSONNEL REPRESENTING KANSAS, NEBRASKA, AND ARKANSAS, AND WILL THUS HELP PROTECT THE US'S ROLE AS THE BREADBASKET OF THE WORLD, SUPPORTING USDA STRATEGIC GOAL 2.

FIRE BLIGHT IS RANKED BY THE U.S. APPLE GROWERS AS THE MOST CONCERNING POME FRUIT DISEASE, WITH ANNUAL ECONOMIC LOSSES AND COSTS OF DISEASE CONTROL ESTIMATED OVER $100 MILLION NATIONWIDE. DUE TO THE LACK OF EFFECTIVE CULTURAL CONTROL, THE MANAGEMENT OF THE FIRE BLIGHT DISEASE RELIES HEAVILY ON ANTIBIOTIC STREPTOMYCIN. HOWEVER, THE LONG-TERM USE OF STREPTOMYCIN HAS FACILITATED THE PATHOGEN TO DEVELOP RESISTANCE. SINCE THE INITIAL REPORT IN 1971, STREPTOMYCIN RESISTANCE HAS BEEN CONSTANTLY OBSERVED IN ALMOST ALL APPLE-PRODUCING REGIONS IN THE U.S. THE CONTINUED USE OF THE ANTIBIOTIC STREPTOMYCIN, ALBEIT BECOMING LESS EFFICIENT, NOT ONLY RESULTED IN CATASTROPHIC LOSSES OF CROPS AND TREES DUE TO FAILURES IN CONTROLLING THE DISEASE BUT ALSO IMPOSES A THREAT TO THE ENVIRONMENT AND HUMAN HEALTH.INSTEAD OF AIMING TO KILL THE PATHOGEN WITH ANTIBIOTICS WHICH FACILITATED THE ANTIBIOTIC RESISTANCE DEVELOPMENT, ANOTHER DISEASE CONTROL STRATEGY IS TO INHIBIT THE VIRULENCE OF THE PATHOGEN. IN OUR PRELIMINARY STUDY, WE IDENTIFIED A SERIES OF SMALL PHENOLIC COMPOUNDS THAT CAN INHIBIT THE EXPRESSION OF KEY VIRULENCE GENES IN THE FIRE BLIGHT PATHOGEN E. AMYLOVORA. WHILE SUCH COMPOUNDS EFFECTIVELY REPRESS THE VIRULENCE OF E. AMYLOVORA, IT HOWEVER DOES NOT AFFECT BACTERIAL SURVIVAL AND GROWTH. WE PROVED THAT SUPPRESSING SUCH VIRULENCE USING VIS COULD POTENTIALLY LEAD TO EFFECTIVE CONTROL OF THE FIRE BLIGHT DISEASE. WE BELIEVE THAT THE VIS CAN PROVIDE A MORE SUSTAINABLE APPROACH IN CONTROLLING FIRE BLIGHT, AS THE VIS DO NOT IMPOSE SELECTIVE PRESSURE ON THE PATHOGEN, THERE IS LESS CHANCE FOR THEM TO MUTATE AND DEVELOP RESISTANCE TO THE VIRULENCE INHIBITORS AS THE ANTIBIOTICS DO. IN THIS PROJECT, WE WILL DETERMINE THE OPTIMAL FIELD APPLICATION CONDITIONS AND EVALUATE THE IMPACT OF THE VIS TO THE ENVIRONMENT. WE AIM TO INCREASE GROWERS' AWARENESS OF THIS NEW STRATEGY AND POTENTIAL BENEFITS. OUR ULTIMATE GOAL IS TO DEVELOP FOR FARMERS THIS NEW MANAGEMENT TOOL AS A VIABLE, COST-EFFICIENT, AND ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY ALTERNATIVE TO THE USE OF ANTIBIOTICS IN AGRICULTURAL DISEASE MANAGEMENT.

IN TURFGRASS, EXTENSIVE TURF DAMAGE IS CAUSED BY A COMBINATION OF INSECT LARVAE ACTIVITY AND THEIR PREDATORS. SOIL-DWELLING INSECTS FEED HEAVILY UPON GRASS ROOTS, WHILE ABOVE-GROUND, THEIR VERTEBRATE PREDATORS DAMAGE TURFGRASS DURING FORAGING BOUTS. A LACK OF ACCURATE MONITORING PRACTICES FOR SOIL-DWELLING PESTS HAS LED TO A RELIANCE ON LARGE-SCALE CALENDAR-BASED PESTICIDE APPLICATIONS, WHICH CAN HAVE A NEGATIVE IMPACT UPON ABOVE AND BELOWGROUND ECOLOGICAL PROCESSES. SIMILARLY, THE INDUSTRY LACKS TOOLS FOR MANAGING GRUB PREDATORS SUCH AS RACCOONS AND SKUNKS, AND IS LIMITED TO COARSE METHODS SUCH AS NUISANCE TRAPPING. IN THIS PROPOSAL WE AIM TO TEST THE EFFICACY OF ACOUSTIC SENSORS FOR DETECTING ROOT-FEEDING PESTS IN LABORATORY AND FIELD CONDITIONS. WE WILL ALSO EXPLORE THE UTILITY OF ACOUSTICS IN ALTERING SOIL FORAGING BEHAVIOUR BY MESO-MAMMALS.

NON-INSECTICIDAL TACTICS FOR SPW MANAGEMENT ARE NEEDED TO REDUCE THE ENVIRONMENTAL BURDEN OF THE CURRENT PROGRAM. RECENT COMMERCIALIZATION OF SWEETPOTATO VARIETIES RESISTANT TO SPW COUPLED WITH RESEARCH SHOWING THAT ISOLATES OF THE FUNGUS METARRHIZIUM ARE EFFECTIVE AGAINST SPW MAY ALLOW COMBINED USE OF THESE TACTICS FOR SUPPRESSION OF SPW EQUIVALENT TO THAT ACHIEVED WITH INSECTICIDES. THE CURRENT USE OF PROPHYLACTIC INSECTICIDE APPLICATIONS IS PREMISED ON THE ASSUMPTION THAT PRESENCE OF A SINGLE SPW LARVAE IN A SWEETPOTATO RENDERS THE ENTIRE ROOT UNUSABLE AS HUMAN FOOD (ZERO TOLERANCE). THIS PREMISE RELIES ON A LIMITED UNDERSTANDING OF FURANOTERPENOID INDUCTION BY SPW AND ITS EFFECTS ON PALATABILITY. THE EXTENT OF TERPENOID INDUCTION BY SPW WILL BE CHARACTERIZED AND CONSUMER SENSORY ASSAYS WILL BE CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE IF THE CURRENT THRESHOLD IS WARRANTED. FINALLY, THE POSSIBILITY THAT MONITORING OF SPW CAN BE IMPROVED USING PLANT VOLATILES WILL BE EXPLORED. THE PRIORITIES ADDRESSED INCLUDE DEVELOPMENT OF TOOLS AND TACTICS FOR MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS AND INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF INTERACTIONS AMONG TACTICS. SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION WILL RESULT IN SPW MANAGEMENT THAT ENHANCES ECONOMIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY FOR THE U.S. SWEETPOTATO INDUSTRY.

THIS IS AN ARDP SINGLE-FUNCTION RESEARCH PROJECT FOCUSED ON PLANT PROTECTION TOOLS AND TACTICS. WE PROPOSE TO EVALUATE THE EFFICACY OF SATURATED STEAM AND ELECTRIC WEED CONTROL AS COMPONENTS OF A NON-CHEMICAL WEED MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. THESE NOVEL TECHNOLOGIES CAN FUNDAMENTALLY CHANGE WEED MANAGEMENT IN HAZELNUT TO MITIGATE HERBICIDE RESISTANCE. HERBICIDE RESISTANCE IS THE GREATEST WEED MANAGEMENT CHALLENGE IDENTIFIED IN MULTIPLE COMMODITIES. IN OREGON HAZELNUT ORCHARDS, THERE ARE CONFIRMED CASES OF RESISTANCE AND MULTIPLE-RESISTANCES TO ALL POST-EMERGENCE HERBICIDES, JEOPARDIZING HERBICIDE MIXTURES AND ROTATIONS AS A MANAGEMENT TOOL. THE USE OF NON-CHEMICAL WEED CONTROLS LIKE TILLAGE IS LIMITED IN HAZELNUT BECAUSE THE NUTS ARE HARVESTED FROM THE ORCHARD FLOOR, REQUIRING A LITTER-FREE AND FIRM SOIL SURFACE. OUR APPROACH INCLUDES FIELD RESEARCH IN COLLABORATION WITH GROWERS AND ON UNIVERSITY FARMS. NEITHER SATURATED STEAM NOR ELECTRIC WEED CONTROL DISTURBS THE SOIL, MAKING THEM COMPATIBLE WITH HAZELNUT. OUR OBJECTIVE IS TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS AND CROP SAFETY OF THE NOVEL TOOLS AS THEY COMPARE TO MOWING OR HERBICIDES. WE PROPOSE TO TEST TOOLS IN ORCHARD MIDDLES AND WITHIN TREE ROWS, AN AREA OF THE ORCHARD OFTEN MANAGED EXCLUSIVELY WITH HERBICIDES. EXPERIMENTS WILL DETERMINE SAFE RATES FOR STEAM AND ELECTRICITY APPLICATIONS WHILE OPTIMIZING WEED CONTROL. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP IDENTIFY EFFECTIVE NON-CHEMICAL WEED MANAGEMENT TOOLS COMPATIBLE WITH TREE NUT PRODUCTION. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE A REDUCTION IN HERBICIDE RELIANCE, MITIGATION OF HERBICIDE RESISTANCE COSTS, AND REDUCED HUMAN EXPOSURE TO CHEMICALS. OUR FINDINGS WILL HAVE APPLICATIONS TO A WIDE RANGE OF OTHER WOODY PERENNIAL CROPS.

NEW CONTROL OPTIONS FOR HERBICIDE-RESISTANT BARNYARDGRASS AND PALMER AMARANTH WERE LISTED AS THE MOST IMPORTANT RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL NEED IN RICE BY MID-SOUTH STAKEHOLDERS. THE INCREASE IN GLOBAL DEMAND FOR RICE AND NEWLY UTILIZED PRODUCTION PRACTICES (FURROW-IRRIGATED RATHER THAN FLOODED) REQUIRE GREATER PRODUCTION EFFICIENCY AND A HOLISTIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE CROPPING SYSTEM. THUS, THERE IS A CRITICAL NEED FOR IDENTIFICATION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF INTEGRATED WEED MANAGEMENT (IWM) TACTICS, INCLUDING CULTURAL STRATEGIES (SUCH AS MANIPULATING THE COMPETITIVENESS OF THE CROP THROUGH ALTERATIONS TO DRILL SPACING) AND OPTIMIZATION OF CHEMICAL CONTROL METHODS (ACHIEVING GREATER SPRAY COVERAGE WHILE REDUCING OFF-TARGET MOVEMENT AND THE NUMBER OF REQUIRED APPLICATIONS), TO BETTER MANAGE WEEDS IN RICE ACROSS THE MID-SOUTH REGION. OUR OVERALL OBJECTIVE IS TO DEVELOP EFFECTIVE IWM STRATEGIES UTILIZING DRILL SPACING AND BED WIDTH (SPACING BETWEEN IRRIGATION FURROWS) MANIPULATION, AND HERBICIDE APPLICATION OPTIMIZATION THROUGH PROPER NOZZLE SELECTION (DROPLET SIZE, SPRAY ANGLE, ETC.) IN COORDINATION WITH THESE CULTURAL STRATEGIES, TO MORE EFFECTIVELY MANAGE WEEDS WHILE REDUCING INPUTS, THEREBY IMPROVING PROFITABILITY AND EFFICIENCY OF RICE PRODUCERS IN BOTH FLOODED AND FURROW-IRRIGATED RICE. FLOODED RICE IS MOST COMMONLY UTILIZED AS IT PROVIDES THE NECESSARY IRRIGATION TO A DROUGHT-SENSITIVE CROP LIKE RICE, WHILE ALSO PROVIDING A CULTURAL WEED MANAGEMENT TOOL TO REDUCE WEEDS THAT CAN'T SURVIVE IN A FLOODED ENVIRONMENT. HOWEVER, THE REQUIREMENTS TO BUILD LEVEES TO SUSTAIN A FLOODED ENVIRONMENT IS VERY LABOR INTENSIVE AND REQUIRES A SIGNIFICANT AMOUNT OF TILLAGE. FURROW-IRRIGATED RICE ALLEVIATES THESE CHALLENGES BY ELIMINATING THE NEED FOR LEVEES, THEREBY SAVING LABOR COSTS AS WELL AS BEING MORE ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY THROUGH REDUCED TILLAGE, FUEL CONSUMPTION, AND METHANE EMISSIONS AS COMPARED TO FLOODED RICE, BUT CREATES NEW CHALLENGES FOR WEED MANAGEMENT. OUR SPECIFIC AIM IS TO CONDUCT FIELD STUDIES EVALUATING THE EFFECT OF DRILL SPACING, BED WIDTH, AND NOZZLE TYPE ON: (1) HERBICIDE-RESISTANT BARNYARDGRASS AND PALMER AMARANTH CONTROL, GROWTH, AND SEED PRODUCTION, (2) HERBICIDE SPRAY COVERAGE, AND (3) RICE LODGING AND YIELD IN FLOODED AND FURROW-IRRIGATED PRODUCTION SYSTEMS. DISSEMINATION OF RESULTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS THROUGH MULTIPLE EXTENSION SOURCES (PUBLICATIONS, ONLINE VIDEOS, DIRECT TEXT MESSAGES, COUNTY EXTENSION AGENTS) TO INCREASE ADOPTION OF IWM STRATEGIES IN RICE WILL BE PRIORITIZED TO DIVERSIFY WEED MANAGEMENT TACTICS, MITIGATE HERBICIDE RESISTANCE EVOLUTION, AND INCREASE PRODUCER PROFITABILITY. ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL HELP INCREASE AWARENESS OF U.S. RICE SUSTAINABILITY. BY INCREASING WEED CONTROL THROUGH SUSTAINABLE MEANS, REDUCTIONS IN WEED SEEDS IN GRAIN CAN BE ATTAINED TO INCREASE EXPORT ACCEPTANCE AND BENEFIT THE NATIONAL ECONOMY. THIS PROJECT WILL ASSIST IN THE CREATION OF A KNOWLEDGEABLE AND COMPETITIVE AGRICULTURAL WORKFORCE (UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS, COUNTY EXTENSION AGENTS, FARMERS, CROP CONSULTANTS, AND MANY OTHERS). FINALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL DEMONSTRATE THE RESOLVE OF U.S. RICE PRODUCERS TO PROVIDE A SUSTAINABLE, SAFE, AND HIGH-QUALITY FOOD PRODUCT THAT CAN BE ENJOYED INTERNATIONALLY.

THE APHID METOPOLOPHIUM FESTUCAE CEREALIUM (MFC) HAS EMERGED OVER THE LAST SEVERAL YEARS AS ONE OF THE MOST ABUNDANT APHIDS PRESENT IN WHEAT SYSTEMS OF NORTHERN IDAHO, WASHINGTON, AND NORTHERN OREGON. MFC CAUSES A CHLOROTIC REACTION IN WHEAT AND OTHER GRASSES, SUGGESTING IT IS ESPECIALLY INJURIOUS. RECENT SURVEYS HAVE DETECTED MFC INDIVIDUALS OUTSIDE OF ITS CORE INVADED RANGE AND INTO SOUTHERN IDAHO AND MONTANA. THUS, WHEAT SYSTEMS THAT ACCOUNT FOR AS MUCH AS 18% OF PRODUCTION IN THE USA ARE POTENTIALLY AFFECTED. TO ADDRESS THIS ISSUE, THIS PROJECT HAS THREE OBJECTIVES: 1. ASSESS THE EXTENT AND DIVERSITY OF MFC INFESTATIONS IN WHEAT PRODUCTION SYSTEMS IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES, 2. DETERMINE THE EXTENT OF MFC DAMAGE AND DEVELOP MANAGEMENT THRESHOLDS, AND 3. DEVELOP NOVEL APHID IDENTIFICATION AND DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS FOR PRODUCERS. OBJECTIVE 1 WILL DELINEATE MFC PRESENCE IN WHEAT AND NON-CULTIVATED PERENNIAL GRASS HOSTS AND DOCUMENT EXPANSION INTO OTHER STATES, ASSESS THE GENETIC DIVERSITY AND PROJECT THE POTENTIAL GEOGRAPHIC RANGE OF MFC IN NORTH AMERICA. TO DEVELOP MANAGEMENT THRESHOLDS, OBJECTIVE 2 WILL EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL ROLE OF MFC AS A VIRUS VECTOR AND QUANTIFY DIRECT FEEDING DAMAGE. THE EXTENSION COMPONENT OF THE PROJECT (OBJECTIVE 3) WILL DEVELOP ONLINE DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS FOR INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT OF CEREAL APHIDS, INCLUDING MFC, WHICH WILL ENTAIL >20% OF TOTAL PROJECT EFFORT. PROJECT OUTCOMES WILL ADDRESS TWO CPPM GOALS: IMPROVED INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT (IPM) PRACTICES, INCREASED IPM ADOPTION.

BROWN STINK BUG, EUSCHISTUS SERVUS, IS THE COSTLIEST AND MOST PROBLEMATIC INSECT PEST OF CORN IN THE SOUTHEASTERN US, AND A MAJOR PEST OF SOYBEAN AND COTTON ACROSS THE SOUTHERN US. SOME EARLY SEASON HOSTS, OVERWINTERING LOCATION, AND THE ASSOCIATION OF PREVIOUS YEAR'S SOYBEANS TO BROWN STINK BUG PREVALENCE IN CORN ARE KNOWN, BUT THESE FACTORS HAVE NEVER BEEN HOLISTICALLY STUDIED TO SEE IF THEY ARE LINKED. WE PROPOSE SUCH A STUDY TO BETTER IDENTIFY CORN FIELDS AT RISK FOR BROWN STINK BUG. WE WILL: 1) MEASURE STINK BUG POPULATIONS IN SUITABLE HOST CROPS DURING THE AUTUMN WHERE CORN WILL BE PLANTED DURING THE SPRING; 2) CHARACTERIZE OVERWINTERING HABITATS BASED ON THE CATEGORIZATION OF HOST PLANTS OR FOREST STRUCTURE; 3) MEASURE BROWN STINK BUG COLONIZATION INTO SPRING CORN ADJACENT TO NON-CROP OVERWINTERING HABITATS AND ANNUAL CROPS; 4) ESTIMATE STINK BUG INJURY IN FOCAL CORN FIELDS; 5) ASSESS CORN YIELDS RELATIVE TO STINK BUG DENSITY AND LANDSCAPE FEATURES; 6) IDENTIFY LANDSCAPES AT RISK FOR INFESTATION BY BROWN STINK BUG AND CREATE A RISK MAP FOR THE SOUTHEASTERN US; AND 7) DOCUMENT BASELINES FOR MANAGEMENT OF BROWN STINK BUG IN FIELD CROPS AND DISSEMINATE BROWN STINK BUG RISK MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATION TO RELEVANT STAKEHOLDERS. WE HOPE THAT BY DOCUMENTING THE SOURCE-SINK DYNAMICS OF BROWN STINK BUG AMONG YEARS THAT WE WILL IDENTIFY KEY COMBINATIONS OF CROPS AND NON-CROP OVERWINTERING HABITATS THAT ELEVATE RISK FOR BROWN STINK BUG COLONIZATION. THIS WILL LEAD TO MORE SCOUTING FOR BROWN STINK BUG IN THE CORRECT PLACES.

THIS ARDP RESEARCH-LED PROPOSAL WITH EXTENSION ADDRESSING CPPM FOCUS AREA (A) PLANT PROTECTION TOOLS AND TACTICS. WE AIM AT DEVELOPING AND DELIVERING EASY TO ADOPT, ECONOMICALLY VIABLE, AND ENVIRONMENTALLY APPROPRIATE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE JOINT MANAGEMENT BROMUS TECTORUM (CHEATGRASS, DOWNY BROME) AND FUSARIUM CROWN ROT, AN INTERACTING PEST COMPLEX THREATENING THE SUSTAINABILITY OF SMALL GRAIN CROPS. TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL, WE WILL: (1) ASSESS THE INDIVIDUAL AND INTERACTIVE EFFECTS OF COMMONLY USED PRACTICES ON THE JOINT MANAGEMENT OF B. TECTORUM AND FUSARIUM CROWN ROT IN WHEAT SYSTEMS, (2) APPRAISE ECONOMIC TRADE-OFFS IN THE JOINT MANAGEMENT OF B. TECTORUM AND FUSARIUM, (3) PRODUCE A DECISION MANAGEMENT TOOL TO MODEL THE RELATIVE IMPORTANCE OF FERTILIZATION, FUNGICIDE USE, AND FUSARIUM CROWN ROT ON B. TECTORUM POPULATION GROWTH, WHEAT YIELD, QUALITY, AND ECONOMIC RETURNS, AND (4) DEVELOP AND DELIVER EDUCATION AND EXTENSION MATERIAL ON THE INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT OF B. TECTORUM AND FUSARIUM CROWN ROT IN SMALL GRAIN SYSTEMS. THE RELEVANCE OF THIS SYSTEMS-ORIENTED PROJECT IS UNDERSCORED BY: (A) THE SELECTION OF B. TECTORUM BIOTYPES RESISTANT TO DIFFERENT HERBICIDE GROUPS, (B) THE IMPACTS THAT B. TECTORUM AND FUSARIUM HAVE ON SMALL GRAIN SYSTEMS, (C) THE ECOLOGICAL INTERACTIONS OCCURRING BETWEEN THESE TWO PEST GROUPS, AND (D) THE MANAGEMENT CONTRADICTIONS THAT EMERGE FROM SINGLE PEST MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS. THE ECOLOGICALLY-BASED PRINCIPLES DEVELOPED IN THIS PROPOSAL WILL ALLOW AGRICULTURAL PROFESSIONALS ACROSS THE SEMI-ARID ENVIRONMENTS OF THE NORTHERN GREAT PLAINS TO DEVELOP INTEGRATED PATHOGEN AND WEEDS MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS WHICH, IN TURN, WILL ENHANCE THE SUSTAINABILITY OF RURAL COMMUNITIES.

CANADA THISTLE (CIRSIUM ARVENSE L.) IS ONE OF THE MOST COMMONLY OCCURRING NOXIOUS WEEDS IN THE INTERMOUNTAIN WEST REGION (DAVIS ET AL., 2018). WITH MANY THOUSANDS OF ACRES CURRENTLY INFESTED, CANADA THISTLE CAUSES SEVERAL (AGRO)ECOLOGICAL PROBLEMS, INCLUDING NATIVE PLANT DISPLACEMENT, REDUCED QUALITY OF GRAZING LAND, AND LOWER CROP YIELDS. CURRENT MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS RELY HEAVILY UPON TACTICS THAT ARE COSTLY, LABOR INTENSIVE, AND NOT OFTEN SUITABLE (E.G., MANY HERBICIDES CANNOT BE USED NEAR WATER). THUS, THERE IS A NEED FOR ALTERNATIVE CONTROL MEASURES. RECENTLY, A NATURALIZED RUST FUNGUS, PUCCINIA PUNCTIFORMIS, HAS SHOWN POTENTIAL FOR CONTROL OF CANADA THISTLE. UNKNOWN, ARE THE DIFFERENCES IN DECLINE WITHIN POPULATIONS AND THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, BIOTA, AND OTHER CONTROL TACTICS, SUCH AS TILLAGE, THAT MAY BE LIMITING THE EFFICACY OF P. PUNCTIFORMIS ON CANADA THISTLE IN THE INTERMOUNTAIN WEST. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE EFFICACY OF P. PUNCTIFORMIS, A NATURALIZED RUST, AND INCORPORATE IT WITH OTHER TACTICS FOR MANAGING CANADA THISTLE. WE PROPOSE TO CONDUCT STUDIES TO FURTHER REFINE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW THE RUST PATHOGEN INITIATES SYSTEMIC INFECTIONS WITH THE GOAL OF INCREASING THE FREQUENCY OF SIGNIFICANT CANADA THISTLE REDUCTIONS AFTER P. PUNCTIFORMIS RUST INOCULATIONS. WE ALSO PLAN TO EXPLORE OPPORTUNITIES TO INCORPORATE RUST INFECTION WITH OTHER TACTICS FOR INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT OF CANADA THISTLE. THE INTRODUCTION OF CLASSICAL BIOLOGICAL CONTROL INTO CURRENT CANADA THISTLE INTEGRATED WEED MANAGEMENT (IWM) REGIMES MAY SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASE CONTROL WHILE REDUCING COSTS.

NEW YORKSTATE IS RANKED FIFTH IN THE COUNTRY FOR ONION PRODUCTION, WITH AN ANNUAL PRODUCTION OF APPROXIMATELY 142,000 TONNES FROM2800 HA EACH YEAR, WITH A VALUE OF $46 M AT THE FARM GATE.STEMPHYLIUM LEAF BLIGHT OF ONION CAUSED BY THE FUNGUS STEMPHYLIUM VESICARIUM HAS EMERGED AS A MAJOR FOLIAR PATHOGEN OF ONION IN NY IN RECENT YEARS. THE DISEASE OCCURS IN OVER 95% OF ONION CROPS EACH YEAR, AND CAUSES PREMATURE DEATH OF CROPS LEADING TO SIGNIFICANT YIELD LOSSES OF 30-40%IN SEVERELY AFFECTED CROPS. AT PRESENT THE ONLY METHOD OF CONTROL IS THROUGH REGULAR APPLICATIONS OF FUNGICIDES. HOWEVER, THE FUNGUS HAS DEVELOPED FIELD RESISTANCE TO TWO COMMONLY USED FUNGICIDES, AND THERE IS EVIDENCE THAT OTHER FUNGICIDES ARE UNDER THREAT. THERE IS AN URGENT NEED TO DEVELOP PRACTICES WHICH EFFECTIVELYMANAGE THE DISEASEWHILE REDUCING THE ONSET OF FUNGICIDE RESISTANCE. THIS PROJECT WILL INVESTIGATE FORECASTING MODELS BASED ON ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS AS A MEANS OF TIMING FUNGICIDE APPLICATIONS IN ONION CROPSMORE EFFECTIVELY, DEVELOP A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE BIOLOGY OF THE FUNGUS SO THAT WEAK POINTS IN THE LIFECYCLE CAN BE TARGETED BY MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES OTHER THAN FUNGICIDES, AND DEVELOP MOLECULAR TOOLS TO BETTER MONITOR FOR, AND ADVISE GROWERS OF, THE EXTENT OF FUNGICIDE RESISTANCE.

THE MOST COMMON CROPPING SYSTEM IN THE SEMI-ARID REGION OF THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST (PNW), WHERE LOW ANNUAL PRECIPITATION PREVENTS ALTERNATIVE CROPS, IS WINTER WHEAT FOLLOWED BY ONE YEAR OF FALLOW. TO SAVE WATER DURING THE FALLOW PERIOD, WEEDS MUST BE CONTROLLED WITH HERBICIDES OR TILLAGE. ONE SIGNIFICANT CHALLENGE TO THESE CROPPING SYSTEMS IS RUSSIAN THISTLE (SALSOLA TRAGUS). RUSSIAN THISTLE IS A CONTINUOUS PROBLEM PROBABLY BECAUSE SEEDS ARE REINTRODUCED TO A FIELD FROM ROADSIDES, DITCHES, AND NEIGHBORING FIELDS BY PLANTS TUMBLING WITH THE WIND. THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE: 1) DETERMINE THE BIOLOGICAL AND ECOLOGICAL FACTORS THAT MAKE RUSSIAN THISTLE A RECURRENT PROBLEM, 2) DEMONSTRATE THAT REDUCING RUSSIAN THISTLE PROBLEMS IS POSSIBLE BY INTEGRATING PRACTICES THAT PREVENT RUSSIAN THISTLE PLANTS FROM TUMBLING, AND 3) PROVE THAT RUSSIAN THISTLE INFESTATIONS CAN BE DECREASED MORE EFFICIENTLY WITH A COOPERATIVE CONTROL EFFORT. TO ACHIEVE THESE GOALS, THE PARTICULAR OBJECTIVES WE PROPOSE ARE: 1) INVESTIGATE ASPECTS OF RUSSIAN THISTLE ECOLOGY AND BIOLOGY TO IMPROVE ITS CONTROL IN DRYLAND CROPPING SYSTEMS, 2) INVESTIGATE HARVEST AND POST-HARVEST STRATEGIES TO IMPROVE INTEGRATED RUSSIAN THISTLE MANAGEMENT IN NO-TILL DRYLAND CROPPING SYSTEMS, 3) EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL OF COOPERATIVE EFFORTS TO IMPROVE RUSSIAN THISTLE CONTROL, AND 4) DOCUMENT AND COMMUNICATE RESULTS TO GROWERS, THEIR ADVISORS, OTHER STAKEHOLDERS, AND THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY. BY IMPROVING INTEGRATED RUSSIAN THISTLE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THE PROJECT SEEKS TO ENHANCE THE ECONOMIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY OF DRYLAND CROPPING SYSTEMS IN THE PNW AND SIMILAR SEMI-ARID REGIONS.

HELICOVERPA ZEA IS A MAJOR TARGET OF PYRAMIDED BT COTTON AND BT CORN IN THE U.S. OVER THE PAST THREE YEARS, GROWERS, AGRICULTURAL CONSULTANTS AND STATE EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS HAVE BEEN REPORTING INCREASING INCIDENCES OF H. ZEA SURVIVING AND INJURING BT CORN AND COTTON IN THE SOUTHERN U.S. THERE HAVE BEEN A NUMBER OF REPORTS OF H. ZEA RESISTANCE TO CRY1 AND CRY2 BT PROTEINS. SUBSEQUENTLY, SOUTHERN U.S. COTTON PRODUCERS HAVE FOUND IT NECESSARY TO TREAT BT COTTON WITH INSECTICIDES TO PREVENT ECONOMIC LOSSES TO H. ZEA. HOWEVER, THERE IS A GREAT DEAL OF CONFUSION AMONG GROWERS AND EXTENSION PERSONNEL REGARDING PROPER IMPLEMENTATION OF ACTION THRESHOLDS AND IPM APPROACHES. THIS PROPOSED WORK WILL EVALUATE AND REFINE CURRENT H. ZEA THRESHOLD RECOMMENDATIONS IN COTTON IN THE SOUTHERN U.S. AND HOW IMPLEMENTATION OF EACH THRESHOLD IMPACTS CONTROL AND COST EFFECTIVENESS. WE WILL INVESTIGATE THE POTENTIAL FOR UTILIZING GRAIN SORGHUM AS A H. ZEA TRAP CROP AND NURSERY CROP FOR NATURAL ENEMIES OF H. ZEA AND HEARNPV INOCULUM FOR HORIZONTAL AND ABIOTIC TRANSMISSION INTO COTTON. BECAUSE THE PROJECT ALSO INCORPORATES UTILIZATION OF HEARNPV IN SORGHUM, DATA GENERATED WILL HAVE DIRECT APPLICATION TO H. ZEA MANAGEMENT IN SORGHUM AS WELL. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL DEVELOP RESEARCH-VALIDATED MULTI-CHANNEL EXTENSION AND OUTREACH PROGRAMING MATERIALS FOR H. ZEA TREATMENT DECISION MAKING AND BIOLOGICAL CONTROL ENHANCEMENT IN COTTON.

THE INVASIVE SPECIES SPOTTED WING DROSOPHILA (SWD) DROSOPHILA SUZUKII IS CAUSING SIGNIFICANT ECONOMIC DAMAGE TO SOFT-SKINNED FRUIT THROUGHOUT THE USA. UNLIKE OTHER FRUIT FLIES, SWD LAYS EGGS INTO MARKETABLE FRUIT. RASPBERRIES AND BLUEBERRIES ARE ESPECIALLY VULNERABLE, ALTHOUGH SWD ATTACKS MANY OTHER FRUIT CROPS AND WILD PLANTS. SIGNIFICANT DAMAGE, INCREASED PESTICIDE USE, AND INCREASED ECONOMIC LOSSES HAVE OCCURRED IN THE USA DUE TO SWD. THE INDUSTRY NEEDS ALTERNATIVE MANAGEMENT APPROACHES TO INSECTICIDES. WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP A MANAGEMENT TACTIC BASED ON MANIPULATION OF SWD BEHAVIOR WITH REPELLENTS AND ATTRACTANTS TO REDUCE SWD INFESTATIONS. WE HAVE DISCOVERED A COMPOUND WE REFER TO AS DCX (PATENT PENDING), WHICH SIGNIFICANTLY DECREASED SWD ATTRACTION TO OTHERWISE ATTRACTIVE FRUIT AND DECREASED INFESTATIONS IN THE LAB AND FIELD. DCX IS APPROVED AS A FOOD ADDITIVE AND HAS A MILD, PLEASANT ODOR. WE HAVE ALSO IDENTIFIED ADDITIONAL CANDIDATE SWD REPELLENTS. OUR SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO 1) OPTIMIZE EFFECTIVENESS OF DCX AS A REPELLENT, 2) EVALUATE THE EFFECT OF DCX RELEASED FROM DIFFERENT DISPENSING TECHNOLOGIES AND IN COMBINATION WITH ATTRACT AND KILL TECHNOLOGY AS A PUSH-PULL SYSTEM, 3) EVALUATE THE IMPACT OF DCX ON BENEFICIAL INSECTS, 4) DEVELOP NEW REPELLENTS FOR SWD. THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE BROAD GOAL OF THE CPPM PROGRAM TO DEVELOP EFFECTIVE, AFFORDABLE, AND ENVIRONMENTALLY-SOUND IPM STRATEGIES FOR MANAGING A SERIOUS ECONOMIC THREAT TO THE SMALL FRUIT INDUSTRY. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE CPPM FOCUS AREA "PLANT PROTECTION TACTICS AND TOOLS.

THIS IS AN ARDP RESEARCH-LED PROJECT ADDRESSING THE CPPM FOCUS AREA 'PLANT PROTECTION AND TACTICS.' THE PROJECT IS ON INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT AND EXTENSION OF ASIATIC GARDEN BEETLE (AGB), AN ANNUAL WHITE GRUB WHICH IS AN EMERGING PEST OF FIELD CORN IN OHIO, MICHIGAN, AND INDIANA. IT IS FOUND IN 24 STATES. HISTORICALLY IT WAS A PEST OF TURF AND ORNAMENTALS BUT IN THE PAST DECADE HAS ALARMINGLY BECOME A SIGNIFICANT PEST OF FIELD CORN AMONG OTHER CROPS. SOME CORN GROWERS IN THE REGION REPORT THAT IT IS THEIR MOST IMPORTANT PEST. WE DON'T KNOW WHY AGB HAS SHIFTED INTO CORN BUT GIVEN ITS CURRENT RANGE IN THE CORN BELT, IF THIS TREND CONTINUES IT MAY BECOME A PEST OF NATIONAL IMPORTANCE. FURTHERMORE, THERE ARE CURRENTLY NO RESEARCH-BASED SCOUTING RECOMMENDATIONS, THRESHOLDS, OR CONTROL METHODS FOR AGB IN FIELD CROPS. IN ESSENCE, IPM DOES NOT EXIST FOR THIS EMERGING PEST. OUR GOALS ARE TO (1) DEVELOP SCOUTING PROCEDURES FOR FARMERS TO IDENTIFY AGB PROBLEM-FIELDS BEFORE CORN PLANTING, (2) DEVELOP AN ACTION THRESHOLD TO GUIDE FARMERS ON MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, (3) EVALUATE THE EFFICACY OF CHEMICAL CONTROLS TO EMPLOY WHEN NEEDED, AND (4) CONDUCT EXTENSION TO COMMUNICATE THIS INFORMATION TO FARMERS. WE WILL ACCOMPLISH THIS THROUGH DETAILED AGB SAMPLING STUDIES, ESTABLISHING THE YIELD-LOSS RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN AGB GRUBS AND CORN, MODELING A THRESHOLD, CONDUCTING CHEMICAL EFFICACY STUDIES, AND GENERATING EXTENSION DELIVERABLES. THIS STUDY WOULD BE THE FIRST TO PROVIDE IPM TOOLS FOR AN IMPORTANT REGIONAL PEST WITH THE POTENTIAL FOR MUCH BROADER NATIONAL IMPACT.

DESPITE THE LONG HISTORY OF HEMP PRODUCTION IN NORTH AMERICA, INDUSTRIAL HEMP BEING GROWN IN THE CURRENT ERA CAN BE CONSIDERED TO BE A NEW CROP IN MOST ALL ASPECTS. HISTORICAL RESEARCH ON THE ARTHROPOD PEST MANAGEMENT NEEDS IS ESSENTIALLY NON-EXISTENT; WHAT IS KNOWN ABOUT THE SUBJECT AT THIS POINT IN TIME IS PRESENTED IN THE RECENTLY SUBMITTED REVIEW ARTICLE (CRANSHAW ET AL. 2019). THIS INCLUDES A SUMMARY OF THE PRESENT STATE OF INFORMATION DERIVED FROM WORK DONE OVER THE PAST THREE YEARS IN THREE STATES (COLORADO, VIRGINIA, TENNESSEE) THAT HAVE MADE SOME EFFORT, INVOLVING GRADUATE ENTOMOLOGY STUDENT RESEARCH, TO DEFINE AND ADDRESS PEST MANAGEMENT NEEDS OF THE CROP.THERE HAVE BEEN SEVERAL IMPORTANT ARTHROPOD PEST PROBLEMS IDENTIFIED ON THE CROP. FOR SOME OF THESE (E.G., CORN EARWORM) INTERIM PEST MANAGEMENT PLANS ON HEMP CAN BE FAIRLY EASILY ADAPTED USING IPM STRATEGIES DEVELOPED TO MANAGE THE INSECT IN OTHER CROPS (E.G., ORGANIC SWEET CORN). WHERE THE PEST IS UNIQUE TO THE CROP (E.G., CANNABIS APHID) STRATEGIES USED TO MANAGE SIMILAR INSECTS (E.G., APHIDS ON GREENHOUSE VEGETABLES) CAN GUIDE DEVELOPMENT OF INTERIM PEST MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR HEMP.HEMP RUSSET MITE IS A SPECIES PRESENTLY THOUGHT TO BE RESTRICTED TO CANNABIS SPP. CROPS WITH ESSENTIALLY NO SIGNIFICANT ASSOCIATED RESEARCH, EVEN REGARDING BASIC INFORMATION ON LIFE HISTORY. AS A RUSSET MITE ON AN HERBACEOUS CROP, THERE IS LITTLE TO GUIDE DEVELOPMENT OF RESEARCH-BASED IPM SYSTEMS; PRESENTLY MOST IS INFERRED FROM INFORMATION DEVELOPED FOR TOMATO RUSSET MITE, THE CLOSEST EXAMPLE OF A CROP PEST SIMILAR TO HEMP RUSSET MITE. THERE ARE VERY SIGNIFICANT DIFFERENCES BETWEEN THESE TWO SYSTEMS INVOLVING RUSSET MITES ON NORTH AMERICAN HERBACEOUS HOSTS (TOMATO RUSSET MITE ON TOMATO; HEMP RUSSET MITE ON HEMP), INCLUDING THE FAR GREATER GEOGRAPHIC RANGE OF HEMP RUSSET MITE AS A SIGNIFICANT PEST SPECIES WITHIN NORTH AMERICA (COAST TO COAST) AND THE FAR GREATER NUMBER OF PRODUCERS WITH INTEREST IN THIS PEST.CURRENT PEST MANAGEMENT TECHNOLOGIES AND PRACTICES USED FOR CONTROL OF HEMP RUSSET MITE ARE INADEQUATE, AT BEST. THIS PROJECT, OVER A TWO YEAR PERIOD, SEEKS TO DEVELOP THE METHODS THAT CAN BE USED TO ELIMINATE HEMP RUSSET MITE DURING THE POINT IN HEMP PRODUCTION, CLONAL PROPAGATION, WHERE IT IS MOST VULNERABLE TO CONTROL. THE DEVELOPMENTS OF THESE METHODS, AND THEIR SUBSEQUENT COMMUNICATION TO HEMP PRODUCERS IN THE UNITED STATES, SHOULD PROVIDE A MEANS TO PRODUCE PLANTS THAT ARE FREE OF THIS PEST OBVIATING THE NEED FOR ANY SUBSEQUENT USE OF PESTICIDES FOR THIS PEST ON HEMP CROPS.THERE ARE THREE RESEARCH-LED OBJECTIVES IN THIS PROJECT:1. DETERMINE EFFICACY OF PEST MANAGEMENT PRODUCTS PRESENTLY ALLOWED FOR USE ON HEMP TO BE USED IN HEMP RUSSET MITE ERADICATION STRATEGIES DURING EARLY STAGES OF HEMP PLANT PRODUCTION;2. DEVELOP THE USE OF HIGH CO2 ATMOSPHERE TREATMENT TO DISINFEST LIVING HEMP PLANTS OF HEMP RUSSET MITE;3. DEVELOP THE USE OF QUANTITATIVE-PCR (QPCR) FOR DETECTION AND QUANTIFICATION OF HEMPRUSSET MITE POPULATIONS ON HEMP PLANTS.THERE IS ONE EXTENSION-LED OBJECTIVE IN THIS PROJECT:1. DEVELOP EFFECTIVE METHODS TO PROVIDE RESEARCH-BASED INFORMATION REGARDING HEMP RUSSET MITE IPM TO HEMP PRODUCERS THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES.

PLUM CURCULIO (PC)AND APPLE MAGGOT FLY (AMF) ARE TWO OF THE MOST IMPORTANT PEST OF APPLES IN EASTERN NORTH AMERICA. TO ACHIEVE COMMERCIALLY ACCEPTABLE LEVELS OF CONTROL, GROWERS TYPICALLY APPLY MULTIPLE BROAD-SPECTRUM INSECTICIDE SPRAYS. GROWERS HAVE EXPRESSED THE NEED FOR VIABLE APPROACHES TO REDUCING PESTICIDE APPLICATION AS THE PRINCIPAL MEANS OF CONTROL AGAINST THESE PESTS. THIS 4-YEAR PROJECT HAS BEEN DESIGNED TO DEVELOP PERMANENT 'ATTRACT-AND-KILL' SITES(A TECHNIQUE THAT INVOLVES BRINGING THE PEST TO A SPECIFIC LOCATION WHERE IT CAN BE KILLED BY VARIOUS MEANS) USING SELECTED PERIMETER-ROW APPLE TREES GRAFTED WITH SIX APPLE CULTIVARS THAT ARE VERY ATTRACTIVE TO PC AND AMF. THUS, MULTI-CULTIVAR GRAFTING IS BEING EVALUATED AS A WAY TO MANIPULATE INSECT PEST BEHAVIOR THROUGH HOST PLANT PREFERENCE. THE PLANNING PHASE OF THIS RESEARCH INVOLVED GROWERS, AND THE PROJECT HAS STRONG GROWER SUPPORT. DOZENS OF TREES HAVE ALREADY BEEN GRAFTED (2018 AND 2019) AT VARIOUS COMMERCIAL ORCHARDS IN MA, NH, AND ME, IN PREPARATION FOR THIS PROJECT.THE TWO RESEARCH OBJECTIVES (85% EFFORT) ARE: (1) TO QUANTIFY THE LEVEL TO WHICH MULTI-CULTIVAR GRAFTED TREES ATTRACT MULTIPLE PESTS, RELATIVE TO NON-GRAFTED TREES, AND RELATIVE TO TREES BAITED WITH SYNTHETIC LURES, AND (2) TO ASSESS THE RELATIVE ATTRACTIVENESS OF VEGETATIVE (FOLIAGE) AND REPRODUCTIVE (FRUIT) TISSUE OF EACH OF SIX APPLE CULTIVARS VERSUS MCINTOSH (CONTROL) TO PC AND AMF AT THREE STAGES OF TREE DEVELOPMENT.THE EXTENSION OBJECTIVE (15% EFFORT) AIMS AT IMPLEMENTING A FOCUSED EXTENSION PROGRAM FOR DELIVERY OF OUTPUTS AMONG GROWERS AND EXTENSION PERSONNEL AND MEASUREMENT OF IMPACTS, AND TO INCREASE GROWER ENGAGEMENT. RESEARCH OUTCOMES ARE EXPECTED TO LEAD TO REDUCTIONS IN AMOUNT OR FREQUENCY OF INSECTICIDES APPLIED AGAINST BOTH PC AND AMF, AND POSSIBLY AGAINST OTHER PESTS. THIS PROJECT ALSO SUPPORTS PARTICIPATORY RESEARCH BY INCORPORATING ON-FARM TRIALS AND HANDS-ON DEMONSTRATIONS AND CONNECTS RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS FROM THREE STATES (MA, NH, AND ME). THE MULTI-FACETED EXTENSION COMPONENT FOR THIS PROJECT HAS BEEN DESIGNED TO REACH OUT TO STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH FIELD DAYS, TWILIGHT MEETINGS, PRESENTATIONS AT LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL GROWERS AND PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES, FARM WALKS AT GROWER COOPERATOR LAND, AND THROUGH PRINTED MEDIA AND WEB-BASED OUTLETS. OUR EXTENSION EFFORTS SEEK TO DOCUMENT SHORT- AND MID-TERM OUTCOMES AND IMPACTS.

SUDDEN DEATH SYNDROME (SDS), CAUSED BY FUSARIUM VIRGULIFORME, SIGNIFICANTLY LIMITS SOYBEAN PRODUCTION IN THE UNITED STATES. MANAGEMENT PRACTICES INCLUDE THE USE OF RESISTANT PLANT VARIETIES AND COMMERCIALLY AVAILABLE, BUT EXPENSIVE, SEED TREATMENTS. WE SEEK TO IMPROVE FARMER PRODUCTIVITY AND MINIMIZE UNNEEDED PESTICIDE USE BY DEVELOPING PRE-PLANT TOOLS THAT ENABLE FARMERS TO MAKE A PRIORI SDS RISK ASSESSMENT OF THEIR FIELDS. THIS WILL BE ACHIEVED USING REMOTE SENSING COUPLED WITH A MACHINE LEARNING ALGORITHM AND VALIDATING A QPCR BASED DETECTION METHOD, BOTH DEVELOPED BY OUR GROUP. WE WILL UTILIZE REPLICATED SDS RESEARCH PLOTS, WHEREBY SOYBEANS OF CONTRASTING SDS RESISTANCE LEVELS ARE COMBINED WITH SEED TREATMENTS, AND COMMERCIAL FARM FIELDS IN ILLINOIS, IOWA, AND MICHIGAN. F. VIRGULIFORME IN SOIL, YIELD, AND SDS SEVERITY DATA WILL BE COLLECTED OVER A THREE-YEAR PERIOD. DATA WILL BE USED TO OPTIMIZE AND DETERMINE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE SDS ASSESSMENT. THE USE OF THE OPTIMIZED TOOL WILL BE SHARED WITH DISEASE DIAGNOSTIC CLINICS, AND ITS UTILITY AND FUNCTION SHARED REGIONALLY AND NATIONALLY THROUGH MULTIPLE EXTENSION-BASED OUTLETS.

CORN AND SORGHUM, TWO ANNUAL CEREALS CAN BE GROWN IN TEMPERATE AND TROPICAL CLIMATIC ZONES AND ARE THUS A VERY DEPENDABLE SOURCE OF FOOD, FEED AND FUEL RELATED PRODUCTS. AN ONGOING CHALLENGE IS IMPOSED BY MYRIAD OF PESTS AND PATHOGENS THAT ATTACK THESE CEREAL CROPS. IN A MODERN AGRICULTURAL SYSTEM, INSECT PESTS ARE TACKLED BY THE USE OF SYNTHETIC CHEMICALS, MANY OF WHICH ARE UNSAFE TO HUMAN AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH. SAFE CROP PROTECTION STRATEGIES ARE ESSENTIAL FOR SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION OF ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT CROPS. IN THIS PROJECT WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP: 1. INSECT RESISTANT CORN AND SORGHUM BREEDING LINES CARRYING PLANT NATURAL COMPOUNDS (FLAVONOIDS) AND 2. ISOLATE AND PURIFY FLAVONOIDS FROM CORN AND SORGHUM TO DEVELOP BIOPESTICIDES.OUR PRELIMINARY AND PUBLISHED RESULTS HAVE ESTABLISHED THAT THE USE OF THESE FLAVONOIDS IS EFFECTIVE AGAINST PATHOGENS AND PESTS OF CORN AND SORGHUM AND OTHER SPECIALTY CROPS. THUS, THIS PROJECT IS CONSISTENT WITH THE NATIONAL RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT GOAL OF THE IPM ROADMAP AIMING TO "DEVELOP LOW-RISK SUPPRESSION TACTICS, INCLUDING USE OF BIOPESTICIDES, BIOLOGICAL CONTROL AND PRODUCTS OF BOTH TRADITIONAL BREEDING AND MOLECULAR GENETIC TECHNOLOGY." THIS PROJECT, INVOLVES A TEAM OF GENETICISTS, ENTOMOLOGISTS, AND GROWERS. PROJECT WILL PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES OF TRAINING STUDENTS IN AN INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM. THEY WILL DEVELOP EXPERTISE IN THE AREA OF PLANT NATURAL COMPOUND CHEMISTRY, GENETIC MECHANISMS OF PEST RESISTANCE AS WELL AS IMPLEMENTATION OF NOVEL AND SAFE IPM TOOLS AND TACTICS.

COTTON BLUE DISEASE (CBD), CAUSED BY THE APHID-TRANSMITTED COTTON LEAFROLL DWARF VIRUS (CLRDV) (GENUS POLEROVIRUS, FAMILY LUTEOVIRIDAE), IS AN EMERGING DISEASE THAT POSES A SIGNIFICANT THREAT TO THE PROFITABILITY OF THE U.S. COTTON INDUSTRY.CLRDV IS REGARDED AS THE SECOND MOST DAMAGING VIRUS DISEASE TO COMMERCIAL COTTON WORLDWIDE AND IS THE FIRST VIRUS REPORTED TO CAUSE YIELD LOSS IN THE SOUTHEASTERN U.S. CLRDV WAS INITIALLY IDENTIFIED IN SYMPTOMATIC COTTON COLLECTED FROM TWO ALABAMA COUNTIES IN 2017. IN 2017, CBD INCIDENCE AND YIELD LOSS WERE ESTIMATED FOR APPROXIMATELY 50,585HA OF COTTON IN SOUTH AL, AND YIELD LOSS WAS ESTIMATED AT AN AVERAGE OF 560 KG/HA ACROSS THIS AREA, WHICH WAS VALUED AT $19 MILLION DOLLARS. IN 2018, LATE-SEASON SURVEYS DETECTED THIS VIRUS IN 23 AL COUNTIES, 14 GA COUNTIES, 13 MS COUNTIES, FL, AND SC. IN 2018, VISUAL SURVEYS OF SYMPTOMS IN SOUTH AL RANGED FROM NEGLIGIBLE TO NEAR 100% INCIDENCE, ALTHOUGH INCIDENCES OF 10-20% WERE MORE COMMONLY OBSERVED IN GA AND MS. A SEVERELY INFECTED FIELD IN SOUTH AL HAD ~100% SQUARE DROP. ALTHOUGH INFORMATION ON THE GEOGRAPHIC RANGE, SYMPTOMS AND INCIDENCE ARE PRELIMINARY THEYDEMONSTRATE THE POTENTIAL FOR THIS DISEASE TO REDUCE PLANT HEALTH AND YIELD. THIS MULTIDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH PROJECT WILL BEGIN ADDRESSING AGRONOMICS, CROP GENETICS, AND INSECT PEST MANAGEMENT COMPONENTS OF COTTON PRODUCTION IMPACTING CBD SEVERITY. KNOWLEDGE WILL BE GENERATED ABOUT APHID POPULATION DYNAMICS RESPONSIBLE FOR VIRUS SPREAD IN THE LANDSCAPE, THE EFFICACY OF CURRENTLY AVAILABLE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO REDUCE VIRUS INCIDENCE AND SEVERITY, AND WILL SUPPORT COTTON BREEDING EFFORTS TO DEVELOP VARIETIES THAT ARE RESISTANT TO CBD. RESEARCH CONDUCTED FOR THIS PROJECT WILL ULTIMATELY RESULT IN INTERDISCIPLINARY MANAGEMENT APPROACHES FOR THIS EMERGING PROBLEM BY PROVIDING VALUABLE KNOWLEDGE, TRAINING TOOLS, AND DATA THAT WILL BENEFIT STAKEHOLDERS IN IN ALL AREAS WHERETHISDISEASEIS DETECTED.

THIS IS AN ARDP RESEARCH-LED PROJECT ADDRESSING THE FOLLOWING CPPM FOCUS AREAS: PLANT PROTECTION TOOLS AND TACTICS AND IPM FOR SUSTAINABLE COMMUNTIES. WITH THE GLOBAL POPULATION INCREASING, FOOD DEMAND AND AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION SUSTAINABILITY ARE BECOMING CHALLENGES FOR THE NEAR FUTURE. PESTICIDE APPLICATIONS PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN CROP PRODUCTION THAT CAN HELP REDUCE CROP LOSS; HOWEVER, CAN CAUSE POTENTIAL ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES. TREE FRUITS ARE HIGH-VALUE COMMODITIES, AND THE TREE FRUIT INDUSTRY IS AN IMPORTANT AGRICULTURAL SECTOR IN THE UNITED STATES. PEST MANAGEMENT IS NECSSARY FOR MAINTAINING THE SUSTAINABILITY OF THE INDUSTRY. THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS STUDY IS TO INTRODUCE AN INTELLIGENT SPRAYER TO TREE FRUIT GROWERS AND TECHNOLOGY ENHANCEMENT FOR THE SPRAYING SYSTEM TO SUIT FOR TREE CANOPY STRUCTURES AND ORCHARD TERRAINS IN PENNSYLVANIA. THREE OBJECTIVES WILL BE CONDUCTED: 1) INTEGRATION OF AN INTELLIGENT SPRAYING SYSTEM AND TECHNOLOGY ENHANCEMENT; 2) THE PERFORMANCE EVALUATION OF THE INTELLIGENT SPRAYING SYSTEM FOR THE EFFICACY OF FIELD CONTROL OF INSECT AND DISEASE PESTS; AND 3) INTELLIGENT SPRAYING SYTSEM STAKEHOLDER/GROWER OUTREACH AND EVALUATION OF POTENTIAL INTEREST FOR ADOPTION. INTELLIGENT SPRAYING TECHNOLOGY IS A NEW PRACTICE FOR THE IPM IMPLEMENTATION. THE GOAL AND OBJECTIVES PROPOSED IN THIS PROJECT FIT INTO THE NATIONAL IPM ROAD MAP. WITH THE FULFILLMENT OF THE PROJECT, AN INTELLIGENT SPRAYER WOULD BE SUFFICIENTLY WORKING IN PENNSYLVANIA TYPICAL TREE FRUIT ORCHARDS. EVEN THOUGH THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE ONLY ON APPLES AND PEACHES, THE TECHNOLOGY AND SYSTEM DEVELOPED CAN BE POTENTIALLY EXPANDED TO OTHER TREE FRUIT CROPS AND AGRICULTURAL CROPS.

HONEY BEES ARE CRITICAL MANAGED POLLINATORS FOR COMMERCIAL PRODUCTION AGRICULTURE, AND INCREASED ANNUAL MORTALITY OF THE POPULATION IS UNSUSTAINABLE. REDUCING VARIOUS STRESSORS TO IMPROVE COLONY HEALTH IS THEREFORE A KEY PRIORITY IN THE PEST MANAGEMENT STRATEGIC PLAN FOR APICULTURE. THE PARASITIC VARROA MITE, AND THE VIRAL PATHOGENS THAT THEY VECTOR, IS HIGHLIGHTED AS A PRIORITY FOR RESEARCH AND EXTENSION TO IMPROVE HONEY BEE HEALTH. PREVIOUS IPM EFFORTS FOR VARROA CONTROL, HOWEVER, HAVE FAILED TO GAIN SIGNIFICANT TRACTION FOR THE APICULTURE INDUSTRY. WE CONTENT THAT THIS IS BECAUSE OF TWO FUNDAMENTAL REASONS: (1) FOCUSING ON VARROA LOAD ALONE, WITH THE SOLE GOAL OF REDUCING THE NUMBER OF MITES, DOES NOT ADDRESS THE COMPLEXITY OF THE VARROA-VIRUS SYNDROME IN ITS ENTIRETY; AND (2) THE LACK OF QUANTIFICATION OF VIRAL TITERS IN COLONIES AS THE PRIMARY MEASURE FOR COLONY HEALTH LIMITED THEIR IMPACT. BECAUSE VIRUSES CAN BE SPREAD VERTICALLY FROM QUEEN TO OFFSPRING AS WELL AS HORIZONTALLY BY MITE VECTORING, THIS ALTERNATIVE PATHWAY IS ALSO CRITICAL TO MAXIMIZE ANY VARROA IPM APPROACH. AS SUCH, OUR OBJECTIVES FOR THIS PROJECT ARE THREE-FOLD.
